There are even tennis courts in Alamo Square park!  Definitely didn't see uncle Joey playing tennis on TV back in the day.

I think part of the reason I thought the park was smaller is due to the disproportionate attention Postcard Row gets vs the other sides.  

In any case,  I'm definitely going back even though we're done filming!
author: Sebastian N.

description:
"Everywhere you look...
There's a heart....
A hand to hold on to.
Everywhere you look....
There's a face of somebody who needs you."

The lyrics that make up the "Full House" theme song seem to echo when you visit Alamo Square and see the infamous "Painted Ladies." Maybe I'm dating myself here, but every time I see that sight I feel nostalgic with memories. 

The park has a bit of a slope so you can get a bit of a hike in and enjoy all of the fantastic historic architecture that surrounds the park. The grassy knoll that makes up the park offers a great place to have a picnic on a beautiful day. Just take a quick stroll around the perimeter park and enjoy the day. 

Alamo Square is one of those parks that has history and a future thanks to the modern entertainment era and the people that flock to is lawn.
author: Chad Y.

description:
I've been here a few times before, but I decided to take a friend here to have a picnic. People always swear by Dolores Park or Golden Gate Park and, don't get me wrong, they are great. But, I prefer Alamo Square any day because you get the view and the ambiance without all the people. 

My friend and I brought a blanket and easily found a place to sit. We weren't surrounded by people and we had a view of the downtown/civic center area and the painted ladies. We brought some snacks because I remembered that there aren't many places right around the park itself. There are some restaurants and convenience stores a few (very hilly) blocks away, but none actually next to the park. 

We spent the afternoon playing games and laying on the blanket people watching. It was the perfect Saturday afternoon activity. Away from the tourists and the hustle and bustle of other parts of the city. If you need an escape and have the chance, go to Alamo Square Park!
author: Erin A.

description: Alamo Square = a beautiful view of the city from here.  From the Civic Center, it's pretty easy to get there by taking the #21 bus.
author: James H.

description:
Protip: When viewing the Painted Ladies, walk halfway up the hill alongside the south concrete wall. Now turn and look at the Ladies... and a great view of the city!


The eastern portion of this park is mostly tourist traffic, whereas the western half is great for dog walking and quieter picnics. Bring a jacket for the east hill, because the winds are fierce starting in the afternoon.
author: Michael T.

description: Sooo...what is this? Pretty much cosigning what Angela Z said. It didn't help that I came on a day that was bitterly cold but it seemed like most of everything is under construction, the houses are diluted, lots of dirt and just overall not a pretty place to hang.
author: Inês L.

description:
I really like this place to come during the daytime when it is a beautiful day. The sunset time is also good but sometimes it is too cold to stay. When you are lucky, you can see a full moon rising behind the ladies!

You also can take a look of other location on this website.
http://www.pashadelic.com/photos/25734
author: Kenji Y.

description: So glad I visited this park and area.  The houses around the area are gorgeous and the famous "painted ladies" were so cool to see.  This is where the Tanner family picnic was filmed in opening scene of Full House. Just a really relaxing and beautiful area to explore.
author: Sapna D.

description: The houses were beautiful but we went during a bad time. They are currently rebuilding the park. So if you're thinking about going make sure you check if the park is still getting rebuilt cause it ruins everything.
author: Jonathan C.

description: Beautiful park with a great view of the Painted Ladies and downtown San Fran directly behind it. (Go up the hill of the park to see the buildings of SanFran). My lady and I grabbed a bagel sandwhich from the cafe two blocks away and brought it to the park to eat. We went, we ate, took pictures and left. Other than that, there ain't much to do there.
author: Leo S.

description:
Such a gorgeous park! With a great view of the city and the Painted ladies!
Its really cool to be standing in the area where they show the Tanner family having their picnic in the opening scene of Full house!
author: Allison P.

description:
Reasons to come here:

1) Unique uphill sloping geography makes for an unusual place to go for a walk, run or dog walk with the reward of breathtaking views of every part of the city from the top

2) Beautiful, unusual trees. They look like acacias, but I don't think they are. Whatever they are, their shape and silhouette is reminiscent of trees found in Africa and Asia.

3) No sketchy people. Imagine that!

4) Convenient park amenities including a fairly clean public restroom, benches and lots of grassy fields make for a great place to spend a day.

5) And finally, to see the Full House houses on Steiner St. Even if you've never watched an episode of this show and have no idea what everyone's talking about, the slanted row of Painted Ladies is a pretty sight in its own right.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Alamo Square was on the top of my bf's must see sites for our trip to San Francisco. It also features the row of houses from the TV series Full House. 

Parking was a nightmare, but definitely doable if you are willing to walk a few blocks. 

I didn't get a chance to stop by the shoe garden, but it was nice to just walk around the park and snap some photos before it got too dark.

Bring a jacket because there is a lot of wind!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The "painted ladies" Victorian homes across from Alamo Square are what you see in the opening credits of "Full House," but the actual house is located a short drive away in another neighborhood.

Alamo Square is much more worth it than passing by the house.  We took a bus here, a longer ride from Union Square than some other places, but it was worth it.  We should've packed a picnic or picked up some food nearby, but we sat on the grass for awhile.  Not a lot of benches or screaming kids like your suburban parks.

Then some people walked by, and I got a huge whiff of marijuana.  Since I was a tourist, I couldn't tell if this was just blatant stupidity (I then saw the cig in his hand), or typical San Francisco since it isn't the 60s anymore.
author: Angela P.

description:
Was visiting the bay area for the 4th just this past weekend and took my boyfriend sightseeing. He's never been to SF before, so it was great to show him  a bit of the city's history.

This is a great place to come, sit for a bit with your lunch or your friend and just take in the view. 

The painted ladies are awesome to see as well, especially if you grew up seeing them in your favorite shows. Genuinely gorgeous homes.

I love SF.
author: April T.

description:
A very nice park to spend some time in. Lots of grassy fields to just sit down, relax and take in the view of the painted ladies and downtown San Francisco. The park also has a lot of steep hills so its a good place to walk around and get some good exercise.

Parking can be tough around here sometimes, but it is fairly close to public transportation. Definitely come here if you want to relax and take in some of the nice sights of San Francisco.
author: Chris S.

description: I absolutely love this area of the city. It is so cute and clean, unlike most parts of SF. The Painted Ladies are located in this area and people come here to sit, relax, have a picnic and take in the beautiful scenery. The park itself it pretty good size so even though it is pretty filled with people, you can always find a spot to sit down and enjoy the view. Also, if you were a fan of the show Full House growing up, this is a place you need to check out!
author: Courtney D.

description:
Not sure why it too me so long to get here but I finally made it over this weekend!

Very cute park to relax, have picnics and play with doggies. Take pictures of the colorful Victorians aka the "Painted Ladies" and the gorgeous view of SF/Financial District right behind. One of my favorite parks in the city!
author: Christine C.

description: Great park. Closed from May to the fall though so keep that in mind when visiting! We didn't know this until we arrived.
author: Ryan T.

description: Really pretty view from the Alamo Square! Seems like a pretty common tourist spot because once you get there, all you see are people taking photos in front of those houses from Full House haha but if you walk through the center through to the other side of the square, you'll see plenty of people hanging out on the grass, dogs running around, and people taking walks. I originally came here with my boyfriend to bring our dog, only to realize their "dog park" was not fenced, just simply an off-leash zone. Our dog is only 5 months so we don't quite trust him running around like that quite yet, but it looked super fun with lots of wide open space, just wished we had brought our older dog with us. Also warning it gets super windy even if you're in the sun so bring a jacket :)
author: Ashley C.

description:
For all the gushing I've heard about the grassy expanses of Dolores Park or the breathtaking views from the Twin Peaks, I am surprised that more SF love isn't directed towards Alamo Square. Though famous mostly for bordering the Painted Ladies of Full House fame, the square is a true hidden gem just northwest of the heart of Hayes Valley. 

Apart from snapping twenty-three pictures of the Painted Ladies like a tourist, the square is the perfect place for joggers to get in a morning run, dog-lovers to flirt with each other via their canine companions, and friends/couples to plop down on the grassy slopes with a blanket and a six-pack of IPAs and watch the sun set over the city. The view here is truly phenomenal, especially at the end of the day. You can see as far north as to the ocean, and as far east as to the glittering skyscrapers in the Financial District. 

During a busy week of adjusting to my new digs in Hayes Valley, going to school, and trying to work out, it was nice to take a break from it all and take a walk to Alamo Square for some clarity. I sat down on a bench near all the lovebirds on the grass, tried in vain to ignore that familiar SF smell of weed in the air, and enjoyed the heart-aching beauty of this city I can now call home.
author: Esther W.

description:
How can anyone not love this park? It gives you the most photographed spot in San Francisco. Yup, it's the view that you most often see on SF postcards which is a row of Victorian houses with the financial district skyline in the background.

For best photography, visit in the late afternoon or during sunset when the sun is shining towards the Victorian houses.
author: Teri Y.

description:
Starts singing the full house theme song: 
 
Everywhere you look (everywhere)
 There's a heart (there's a heart)
 A hand to hold on to.
 Everywhere you look (everywhere)
 There's a face of somebody who needs you.

hhehe...that songs always comes up when I go to visit the alamo square and the painted ladies...parking is a burden...you may have to park somewhere far just to get to here. The last time we went it was quiet because it was drizzling and we were pretty lucky getting close parking to one of the painted lady...

At first we were like the full house house was one them but apparently it's not...the house is around the area but approx a couple blocks down. You can lounge at the park when it's sunny. The time I went before the last it was sunny and it's just fun looking at the sky...the weather is no joke in San Francisco, you look up at the sky and the clouds are freakishly moving but so fascinating.
author: Crystal H.

description: Amazing views and fun to see the Tanner house! Beautiful green grass and fragrant trees! Dogs can run off leash and kids can play at the park!
author: Stacy P.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PARK. Prolly one of my favorite places in the city.

And do you remember this? 

Everywhere you look (everywhere)
There's a heart (there's a heart)
A hand to hold on to.
Everywhere you look (everywhere)
There's a face of somebody who needs you.

If you do, then chances are you'll love it even more.

Bring a blanket, some snacks and enjoy the sun, view, and cuties :D
author: Dominique F.

description:
I find this park enchanting.  I even like it better than Golden Gate Park.  It's hilly, beautiful green grass, gorgeous trees, and it's QUIET.  Good enough for me.  And it's across the street from probably the most photographed scene in San Francisco besides the Bridge.

This pic I took is of the Painted lady on the corner of Steiner and Grove that is still for sale for $3.9 million as of April 2010.
author: David S.

description: Cute little park with the view of the painted ladies as well as the city skyline. It's a great place to take visitors. Parking isn't bad but you might have to walk a couple blocks.
author: Vika N.

description: A must stop when you visit San Francisco.  One of the most iconic views in the city.  Scroll through the pictures and you will see why.
author: Paul W.

description: I absolutely love the painted ladies!!!  however, it's probably best to go before the sun starts creeping up so that you can capture a better picture or later on the evening :)
author: Brooke W.

description:
Everywhere you look (everywhere)
There's a heart (there's a heart)
A hand to hold on to.
Everywhere you look (everywhere)
There's a face of somebody who needs you.

This is of course one of the quintessential stops for a SF tourist, so of course I had to visit.  The park is beautiful, and it was bustling on a Sunday afternoon.  It seems like a lovely park for packing a picnic and lounging around.  I do appreciate that they have bathrooms as well.

One of the great allures of the park is to see the famous painted ladies a la Full House fame.  I recommend pulling up the theme song as you're strolling through the park to bring up some cherished childhood memories.  Unfortunately one of the famed painted ladies is being renovated which puts a damper on the pictures we're of course all eager to take.  The nerve!  I'm sure it'll look great when it's finished though.

Just don't be annoying.  I watched a tourist ding dong ditch one of the famed Victorians.  Seriously?!  What's the point?  Don't be that person.
author: Elizabeth W.

description: It's so sad we are in such a drought. This used to be my favorite square as a kid. So many hills and green grassy areas to run around but now there isn't much grass anymore. Makes complete sense but doesn't make it the beautiful park it once was. In my opinion you can skip this park now in your touristy travels. The only reason to visit is the painted ladies but if you don't care to see them this park is not worth your visit.
author: Jena D.

description:
Very nice park!  If you're coming at it from the east on foot, it's a hike uphill, but worth it for the views and the peace and quite in the sunshine!

My one regret is that we did not have a chance to walk around the entire park.  We came here to see the row of famous Painted Ladies houses, which we did (they are very nice, but a bit overrated perhaps).  We plopped down in the grass and just enjoyed the rest for a while.  Dogs ran by and kids played on the playground, which has a nice Victorian houses theme to it.  

Great place!  Wish we could have stayed longer (it was getting cold and we had a dinner reservation to catch!).
author: Johanna K.

description: This is often a forgotten spot to bring tourist.  Not everyone remembers to come here since it's often over shadowed by the Golden Gate bridge, Palace of Fine Arts, and Lombard street. But if you are tour guide for a day and you are starting from the peninsula don't forget to stop by here. If you are coming from the peninsula, i would recommend hitting up twin peaks first, followed by Alamo square, Palace of Fine Arts, Golden gate and lombard street.  I never ever have a had time finding parking here.  You can either find it as you circle around the park or on the side streets.  Once you find parking the painted ladies or the Full house backdrop is on Steiner.  So you would want to face that direction for that perfect shot.   Overall, it's a fairly clean park. There are people who don't pick up after their dogs.  There is also a mini playground here for you to bring your kids.
author: Belinda C.

description: beautiful park to hang out in. since it's on a hill, it has a great view all around, although due to the hill it can also get a bit chilly up there sometimes, especially since it's san francisco after all. the painted ladies are great to see, but there's also more views if you walk along the path and through the dog park
author: Bianca C.

description:
While walking along Steiner, I came upon this park known more for the views of the Painted Ladies than the grounds itself. The park has much to offer. Great hills to work your quads, excellent weather for those who hate the heat, and a charming well-maintained playground for the little ones. 

As you can probably imagine, parking in SF is at a premium, even in a residential neighborhood. Good luck finding much during the weekends, where tourists abound. However, if you can walk or ride a bike here, it's much more convenient. 

There's a ton you can do to enjoy the amenities, Throw a Frisbee along the rolling green hills, take a nap under one of the majestic trees, or enjoy a picnic on one of the park benches or picnic tables. The only drab thing to say is the bathroom is a bit dingy and gross. But what do you expect from a public park restroom?
author: Andy P.

description:
"Trying to find Full House..." 

Finally came here yesterday to check out this lovely park. You get a nice view of the city skyline & the Painted Ladies. Cute playground area for little kids to play their little hearts content. 

It's definitely a nice park to hangout to relax or have a picnic. :)
author: Amy C.

description: Ahh full house.  It took me a year to finally see Alamo Square.  I made my friend drive around the block so I can take a quick picture of the Painted Ladies homes really fast.  Definitely a nice park and a cool tourist spot.  It wasn't that crowded which was nice.
author: Chrissie O.

description: Came here the second time with my mum on labor day and I must declare the views are super awesome. It does not matter if you are from the Bay Area or outside the US this is a must see site in SF. Good for taking photos is what matters the most. If you have a dog feel free to bring them, they will enjoy it
author: Michael W.

description: Alamo square is a beautiful park  and there are amazing Victorian homes around the park but who can  forget the famous show full house has parts of this location where in the show. Very nice green space to lay out on or sit and look at the views and relax in this quiet neighborhood. A must see on the bucket list.
author: Edwin R.

description:
I love a dog-friendly park, and this one has world-class bonus views. We swung by on a walk around the city this gorgeous January day. It was great to hang out in the sun with all the happy people and dogs.  

Now I find out there's a shoe garden? Must return!
author: Elaine L.

description: ROBBED!! Our car was broken into while we were taking pictures.  We parked our car on Fulton street and went to take pictures of the Painted Ladies. We were gone less than 30 minutes! Came back to our car to find shattered glass and multiple cars broken into in broad daylight! Be careful in this area.
author: Alvin C.

description: Even though there are hoards of tourists that come here to get a picture of the scene in the opening credit from Full House, it's not a tourist trap.  The park sits on top of a hill and has a beautiful view of not only the painted ladies but of the city itself.  There is a fountain and lots of green to picnic and lay in the sun on nice days.  There is also tennis courts, a playground, restrooms, benches, picnic tables and water fountains.  The park is dog friendly, there is even a fountain at dog level.  I love coming here for sunset and on sunny days.  It's also a great place to watch fireworks whenever the fog isn't heavy.  If you need picnic supplies, run over to Bi-Rite on Divisadero for supplies.  A very picturesque way to spend a lazy afternoon or kill an hour or two.
author: Kristi G.

description: I enjoyed my quick visit to photograph the painted ladies. It looks like a popular spot for locals and tourists alike. It would be a nice place for a picnic.
author: Alison M.

description: Does anyone know where full house house is? I keep thinking that one of those 4 victorian houses were it. Anyway, this park is full of tourists and selfie sticks. I am totally guilty of being a tourist with a selfie stick as well. I didn't explore the entire park, but it's just a regular hilly park where you can have picnics and you can do your daily run. To be honest, no one is here to enjoy the park. They're all here to take pictures of the houses to post on social media. I am guilt of this lol.
author: Tammy L.

description: This park is near JapanTown. I usually do my evening run there. The park is very nice,there is a dog area as well as children playground,but what makes it wonderful is the "painted ladies" townhouse. And the ciew of SF financial district.
author: Kynan J.

description:
Anytime I have guests come in from out of town, I take them here for an afternoon picnic...providing the weather isn't too windy.  It's a great photo opportunity for them with Postcard Row in the background and it's perfect to get our dog out of the house.  Signs around the park say "keep dogs on leash" but there's always dogs off of their leashes...mine as well.  Dogs have always been well behaved when I am there.  The park gets crowded on hot days but never too uncomfortable.  

Here's my tip:  Grab an Ike's Place sandwich to enjoy while relaxing in the park.
author: Maggie G.

description: There was some construction going on by the park... But other then that, very chill park. We put a blanket down and played some board games. PERFECT!
author: Fatima M.

description:
Everywhere you look, theres a heart, theres a heart. A hand to hold on to!! Full House man. Never had an urge to You Tube it after it stopped playing until this day. I didn't, but I had the urge.

Beautiful little park, up and down hills, good for a work out. Like I said, check out the Full House setting. Not much else. We took "Action Bronson squat pics" hahaha and almost stepped in dog ish, thats nice. Lots of animals here, I guess its the parks theme. It was a very calm, tranquil place though, almost like a scene from a movie. There were dogs playing together, a playground full of children, people laying out on the grass relaxing and even a guy blowing huge bubbles on top of the hill. Gave me more love for the city.
author: Steve L.

description:
Alamo Square is located in the Western Addition and the Park consists of four city blocks at the top of a hill overlooking much of San Francisco. I've walked through this park, ran by it during the Bay To Breakers, and waited here for Gayle to come by during the Susan G. Komen Walk for the Cure. Several bus lines also cross here, so a Visitor should have no problem either walking here or taking public transit. I would also limit my visits to the daytime hours. 

The park includes a playground and a tennis court, and on a clear day, the Transamerica Pyramid building and the tops of the Golden Gate Bridge and Bay Bridge can be seen from the park's center. Then of course there are the Victorian Houses - "Painted Ladies", which is one of the signature San Francisco Tourist pictures. I sometimes wonder how the people who actually liver there put up with the traffic.
author: Eric B.

description:
Awesome View of the city from this park!
This park is great for dogs or just a nice stroll around the park. It has a spectacular view of the city along with old houses that were filmed in tv shows such as full house. It is also near a farmer's market where one can buy either fresh fruits, veggies, alfredo pasta or seafood. Alamo square is also near a really popular restaurant called NOPA. So come here to relax or to walk your dog in this awesome park!
author: Mimi V.

description: Full House! Great for tourist photos and a must visit if you've never been here. Been here a couple of times for frenchie meetups, but my only gripe is that the grass is a little dirty and trash is present.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Gorgeous view of the city at any time of day - twilight, afternoon, witching hours all have their own sense of enchantment. 

It can be a bit windy though. If you're planning a picnic on a Sunday afternoon that weather.com promises to be a fair temperature - beware! The elements of San Francisco may have something else for you in store :p
author: Michelle J.

description:
I was in the Bay area visiting family and we were doing the touristy things. Alamo Square was just one more thing to do.

Lots of people, tour buses, cameras, dogs, and the television series backdrop of Full House was there for all to be seen and pose in front of. (see my photos)

I was there on a particularly cool foggy morning, but Alamo Square is still a sight to be seen. As a tourist destination, this place was not even on my radar.

Parking can be a problem for those who don't know how to parallel park on a hill, but take your time. Many tourists will come and go and you will find parking.

When here, also make note to visit the Alamo Square Shoe Garden. It is a place in the middle of the park where people put plants in shoes. It is neat and interesting to see how creative people can be with a plant and a shoe. (see my photos).

Five Yelp Stars for this tourist trap of San Francisco!

Alamo Square is a little hidden gem to be seen by all.

=)
author: Albert E.

description:
"CUT IT OUT" I have finally made it to the park to take a view of the famous homes from the Full House opening credits. These Victorian houses are the best-known groups of "Painted Ladies" in SF. It is also known as "Postcard Row" The homes werebuilt between 1892 and 1896. 

It is nice park to end up after a walk around the city. Bring something to lay down because the park is sloped so you can take in the view of the "Painted Ladies" and of the city. Its not the best view of the city skyline, but your there more for the place where the Tanner TV family grew up.
author: Justin C.

description: Great views!  It makes you want to watch some Full House reruns!
author: Mike B.

description:
Great location.  Easy to get to.  Nostalgia factor with full house.  Those are the positives.  Unfortunately this fog haven doesnt have a fence for the dogs and it's atop a very steep hill so if your doggie is prone to run off or chase things you should avoid this dog park.

I would only bring my puppy back when she's better at listening and obeying verbal commands.
author: Kenyon S.

description: One of my favorite parks to visit when in SF the view here is amazing overlooking the painted pink ladies and in the back a gorgeous view of the city.
author: Monique C.

description:
If you watched Full House, this is the park where they have the picnic at the end of the opening credits and also where Conan and Bob Saget mocked the show when he brought Late Night to SF.

It was such gorgeous day in the city and we had a great view of the SF skyline behind the Painted Ladies (the houses).  The best time to go is during the afternoon when the sun starts to set in the west. My friends and I had a fun time just relaxing. I know it's a very touristy thing to do, but it's something I needed to do before I moved out of CA.

FYI - If you want to go to the actual Full House house where they "lived", that's located near Broderick and Pine.
author: Rhoda G.

description: It's where you get the best views of the Painted Ladies.  Walk up the stairs to the top of the hill and enjoy this relaxing park. Parking can be a challenge, other than that well worth the trip.
author: Nick G.

description: This place is so beautiful, especially when you climb uphill to check out the breathtaking view of the San Francisco skyline. My sister insisted on coming here since Alamo Square is known for being in Full House. So much fun and can't wait to visit again!
author: Debra T.

description:
Really nice place to big the pups and take them off their leash! If we weren't on vacation and my pup was here, I'd definitely take him for a fun walk at Alamo Square!

The view is beautiful as you have to hike a short hill up to reach this top. It's also a popular place for you Full House fans to see the Painted Ladies! So pack a lunch and charge that battery for your camera because SNAP! SNAP! and CHOMP! CHOMP! You can do it all here and have fun in the sun.
author: Linda D.

description:
Situated on a hill, this park has beautiful views of downtown SF.  My brother brought me here to show me the famous "painted ladies" of SF, as shown famously in the opening credits of the 80's sitcom, Full House.  I'd have to say it, as a someone who used to watch Full House, that it was absolutely nostalgic to see these homes up close and personal.

In regards to the park itself, there were many people taking advantage of the gorgeous SF weather by either walking or playing with their dogs, reading a good book, or just enjoying people watching and good conversation.

Wonderful place to sit and relax while in SF =)
author: Michael C.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco all my life, and yesterday was the FIRST time I've ever stepped into Alamo Square.  Sure, I've seen the postcard photos hundreds of times, recognized the shot on TV's Full House, run passed it during the Bay to Breakers many times and rode pass it on MUNI a gazillion times, but I'd never walked onto the park grounds until yesterday morning.

A volunteer project brought me here.  We spent the morning scraping weeds off of the cracks and crevices along the sidewalk and curb on the Fulton Street and Steiner Street sides of the park.  We encountered numerous tour buses and even had our photos taken by some of the tourists.  Many stopped to ask about our organization (One Brick) and our work.

After the work was done I had a chance to walk around the park.  The park appears to be super dog-friendly, but wow, what fantastic views of the City's skyline!  Even on a gray, overcast morning like yesterday the views were spectacular.  There are lots of grassy areas too and a cool children's playground which incorporates the inspiration of the nearby "painted ladies" into its design (pictured).  

I still can't believe it's taken me a lifetime to discover this park.

BTW - Kudos to the Friends of Alamo Square organization who brought us water, hot coffee, bagels, breakfast pastries and some super, moist and decadent chocolate brownies.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Going to Alamo Square is nothing to write home about other than being able to get to see the Painted Ladies which you'll do from here. It's a good park for people watching as well as catching you breath and avoiding cardiac arrest from walking to the top of it just to see a part of 90's television history.
author: Joshua C.

description:
Came here with friends on 4th of July after reading Wes M.'s review that it was a great place to come see fireworks!

You are able to see the higher fireworks, but the lower ones are covered by buildings. It was still great, because we could see the show and didn't have to deal with all of the people at Fisherman's Wharf.

Also, you'll meet some fine San Franciscan folks. The group behind us kept singing, "Happy Birthday to you! Happy birthday to you! Happy BIRTHDAY DEAR AMERICA!"
Over. And over.
author: Emily D.

description:
Every once in a while, I have to remind myself that this park exists. And then I trek up the major Alamo heights hills to this beautiful view of the city, to reflect for a while.

Make sure it's a pretty nice day though, otherwise this park tends to get really windy! Otherwise... make sure you have a jacket or something.
author: Mike C.

description: Nice park with some beautiful views. Grab some coffee or bring an inconspicuous alcoholic beverage  of your choice,  face east toward the city and you're set. Great place foe dog lovers or a nice place to chat with a loved one. TIP: On CLEAR NIGHTS  stay an extra 30 minutes after sunset for a nice evening view of the city lights turing on.
author: Nathan R.

description:
Perfect spot to view the famous Painted Ladies...you see people setting up their cameras hours ahead of time to capture them in the perfect lighting.

What I really enjoyed most was watching all the off leash dogs run around and play.  There seems to be a good number of regulars there, nice sense of community.  Cute!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Went to Alamo square to see the "painted ladies" and check out what the hype was all about. Ummm, mixed feelings on this place. 

Painted Ladies - reminded me of a Polish saying, "the older the lady, the pinker the dress." The houses need some work - paint is peeling and the houses are showing their age. 

Alamo Park - this is a nice sot with a great view of the citywide - on a clear day you can see the ocean and the bay bridge area. Nice stop to just have a sandwich or play with your dog.
author: Jake K.

description:
after searching for parking around dolores park for eons, i suggested to my friend, what about the park that faces the full house houses. she'd never been after living in the city, and agreed. found VIP parking (but observed someone bumping it trying to park in front of her car, no damage done, thank god), but GOOD TIMES. not as crowded as Dolores Park, even though we saw a lot of tourists (but we felt like tourists taking pictures as well). was fairly empty, and although it wasn't as warm as it was around Dolores Park, weather was fabulous for SF, and drinking our rose champagne, couldn't have asked for more.

theres even a bathroom, it's not the greatest (one stall door was broken), but pretty clean for SF standards!
author: Denise L.

description:
I saw the full house house. I think I saw uncle Jesse taking out the trash, but probably not.

I had an amazing nap. pretty much re-energized my entire day.

Lots of doggies running around and overall fun tiems!
author: Javi N.

description: A beautiful park with a great view of the city, and Painted Ladies.  Good spot for some green beneath your feet and to get in a walk.
author: Courtney L.

description:
It's the Full House park =)

How can you not love how this park makes you reminisce on being a kid and watching DJ, Stefanie, and Michelle Tanner grow up??!!?
Especially when the weather is not foggy, too cold, and the sun's out. 
Reminds me of Union Square...you're in the big city but, still feels homey. Great for picnics, chillin, or walks with the doggie!
author: Laurie V.

description: Alamo park is dog friendly and has some cool views of the city. Plenty of clean benches to sit on. The grounds are in need of maintenance. However, the city has no money and is completely incapable of managing money. So parks like this are adequate, but improvements are few and far between.
author: Robert H.

description: Let's face it, people visit Alamo Square for one reason and one reason only, and that is to see the houses from Full House!  These houses are formally known as the "Painted Ladies."  Nice park, although no Tanners to be seen.
author: Daniel B.

description: On a beautiful day, it is amazing to have a picnic with your friends or to have a date there :D My boyfriend was stressed out that day, but I took my boyfriend there and surprised him with a picnic. His stress was out the window. The dogs there, the city scenery, and the beautiful day made him mellow :) So good there if you need to de stress! :D Plus, it was nice to be reminded of Full House LOL.
author: Jeca V.

description: I don't think I'll ever get sick of walking though this park on a beautiful day in San Francisco and peering in all directions at the gorgeous views our lovely city has to offer. How spoiled are we to have a place like this right in the center of town?! Why anyone lives in Cleveland, I'll never know.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
It's a park...with a view. 
(see pic)

...and halfway through our awesome "view", I smelled poop.
just sayin'
author: Sherri K.

description:
What ever happend to predictability?
The milk man, the paper boy, evening T.V
You miss your old familar friends, but
waiting just around the bend.

Everywhere you look (everywhere)
There's a heart (there's a heart)
A hand to hold on to.
Everywhere you look (everywhere)
There's a face of somebody who needs you.

When you're lost out there and your all alone
A light is waiting to carry you home
Everywhere you look.

You got it dude...
author: Nino R.

description:
Little House's on a Hillside, Little House's on a Hillside..........

One of my first Picnics in SF was at Alamo Square, even though it was a gorgeous day and it was a Saturday at noon, somehow I still found a beautiful patch of green grass, where I laid myself down. 

Such an amazing self realization moment, when you sitting on that green patch. There is no way you can sit there with a frown on your face. Once you settle in and stare at the gorgeous view of the  painted ladies with SF's skyline as your background, all your worries melt away, and your overcome with a sense of personal nirvana.  

I'd say somewhere in Alamo Square is the answer for World Peace.......
author: Lannette G.

description: Alamo Square is a great open area for dogs and people to walk and enjoy the city's view. There are tennis courts, bathrooms, an open grass area and dog park. Come on a sunny day but always bring a jacket! San Francisco weather changes drastically. There are many places to eat around the area too if you just want to stop by for the view.
author: Joanna T.

description:
Sighhhhh. How could you not LOVE Alamo Square? The view of the city is BEAUTIFUL, it's never very crowded (except during Bay to Breakers), and it brings back so many fond memories of watching Full House as a child. 

If you're in need of some sustenance and liquids to get you through a long day of park-lounging, Alamo Square Market & Deli on Scott and Hayes has great sandwiches.

Probably my favorite park ever.
author: Talia G.

description: The Painted Ladies are cute, sure, but not very interesting in the grand scheme of things. So if you're visiting Alamo Square for the Painted Ladies, that's perfectly fine, but a three star experience. Now if you're coming to Alamo Square with your dog (or leashed cat!) and maybe some friends, relax a bit, play with your beloved pet, then Alamo Square is a five star experience. It really is a great dog park but as far as touristic attractions go, you've seen everything you need to see within five minutes. Or less actually because we in fact kept on walking up from Alamo Square when we first got there because we all thought "Seriously? That's it? This can't be it, this is nothing, we must be in the wrong square!". But we weren't. This was seriously it, this was the right square and the most amazing thing there was a couple relaxing with their leashed cat and puppy.
author: Bekkah R.

description: If you want to check out the houses in the show Full House, this is the place to go!
author: Danny N.

description: I really love this park, as do my dogs!  Half of it is an off leash dog area, and even though it isn't fenced in, it's up above the street and feels like a really safe area for the pups.  The park itself is really pretty and well maintained, and as far as I've seen all the dog owners clean up after their pets.  The dogs have fun playing, owners enjoy chatting, it's a great place for you and your furry friends.  Then on the other side of the park you can relive your childhood with the Full House houses (never gets old).  There is also one tennis court and a fenced-in play area for children :)
author: Allison R.

description:
I happen to think this park kinda sucks. The one upside is the views of the painted ladies (aka: full house houses).

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Painted_Ladies

It's on a hill so you can't really play a decent game of soccer or basketball.

I've heard it is popular for dog owners.  Apparently it's not popular among non-dog owners as we get to step in dog shit all day long.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Pros: Nice views, quiet, some shade, right size, great for a picnic.
Cons: Windy. Some people are not responsible with their dogs.
author: Pablo D.

description:
(cue Full House theme song)
What can I say? I love SF. 

Great park with vast expanses of grass for dogs to run off leash and play. Keep in mind, nothing is fenced in so make sure your animal is obedient and well-trained. There is an area just for dogs but they are allowed everywhere else in the park as well. All owners seemed very responsible, picking up after their dogs and watching them closely. 

If you don't have a dog, this is the perfect spot to grab a blanket and have a picnic on the grass. Parking is pretty easy and the are barely any crowds...besides the usual group of tourists huddling around with their cameras snapping photos of the Painted Ladies. There is also A tennis court...but it is SINGULAR. Only one. That I could see anyway. 

Parking was not that bad in this area and no large crowds. Love!
author: Vivian D.

description:
Just another breakt-takingly beautiful SF park, that makes you sad at your lack of financial ability to living in these houses, and leaves you with the Full House theme song stuck in your head.

EVERYWHERE YOU LOOK....
author: Jamie S.

description:
Honestly, who cares about the Fullhouse houses?

This park is great regardless, and if I lived in this area I'm sure I'd be hanging around here most of the time. Fun dog watching, incredible view, even at night.
author: Jessie M.

description:
I honestly don't think this view could ever get old.

Seriously - can't get it out of my mind.

People laying about - drinking wine, beer... listening to music.. just enjoying the city.  It was oh so charming.

If you're visiting you need to make a stop at Alamo Square... IMO.
author: Tony K.

description:
I hate to blow up the spot, but this is one place in SF that is ironically both the best kept secret here as well as one of the hottest tourist attractions.  I see tour buses and tourists here all the time, but whenever people ask me where I live and I say "Alamo Square", they're like "huh? where's that?"

For visitors, it's a must see simply for the amazing vantage points to take some postcard worthy photos.  You can see the famous row of painted ladies that are featured in the opening credits of Full House (and on countless postcards and souvenirs).  On a clear day, you can also get a fantastic view of the city skyline as well.  

For locals, it's a great place to bring your doggies.  There's an off leash area where the puppers can run free.  Just be careful as sometimes people aren't very careful with their own dogs.  If you have a small dog, be mindful that there may be large aggressive dogs running around.

Parking is not too bad during the day, but after about 6pm it can be a b*tch.  

As a neighborhood to live in, well it's pretty awesome if you can find a spot that's affordable.  It's super close to Hayes Valley, Pac Heights, the Fillmore, Lower Haight, etc.
author: Preethi C.

description: Growing up in the 90's and watching Full House, we were not going to miss the Alamo Square and the famous Full House house. On the other side of the park was a nice view of the city, which was breathtaking. There were lots of people sitting and relaxing. I won't see that in Long Beach. You can't miss visiting the Alamo Square if you are visiting San Francisco.
author: Neang C.

description: Beautiful spot on the hill to get a picture of the Full House houses! I loved this spot on our sightseeing adventure. Bus takes you right there & it wasn't overly crowded. Great views of the city from atop the hill.
author: Dawn R.

description:
So I live like 2 blocks from here and its really nice. I walk by them all the time cuz its a nice little uphill workout. Plus the park is really nice, well-kept, and the scenery of the Painted Ladies and the city behind them is gorgeous!
Its really nice on a warm day. Just lay out in the sun on the grass. Everyone minds their own business, people are really good about picking up after their dogs, there are restrooms if needed, and even a tennis court.
author: Mandi W.

description:
My apartment is about equidistant between Dolores Park and Alamo Square Park. Alamo Square Park feels like the quieter, less outrageous, less warm and significantly less in-your-face cousin. Where one can REALLY get some reading done, not just watch kooky people get drunk and toked up.

The doggies here are cute and don't take over the space like my neighborhood park, Duboce Park.

I get a kick out of taking visitors here to show them the full house houses. If I am not here with out-of-towners, avoiding that side of the hill is best to maximize the peace and quiet this park can provide compared to other major parks in the city.
author: Denise B.

description: I love this park!  There's always people on the grass laying on a blanket with a view of the Painted Ladies and the city in the background.  There's plenty of street parking during the day.  Highly recommended to bring tourists here or to have a picnic!
author: Chris L.

description: I don't understand why anyone would give this park less than 5 stars! Alamo Square is huge, if you're lucky, there's tons of parking nearby, and if you're not so lucky it's easily accessible by public transportation, walking distance from many eateries, clean, and most importantly, has one of the best views in SF. Remember Full House with the row of houses? Those houses are right in front of you along with a nice view of the city! If you go on the other side of the park, you have a wonderful view of Twin Peaks. Seriously, the best park ever.
author: Joyce E.

description: Awesome park with a great view of the TransAmerica building and City Hall! Come relax on the hillside and enjoy SF =)
author: Sam F.

description:
**Cue in the Full House theme song......

I'm such a tourist so of course I came here just to see where the characters of one of my fave shows growing up frolicked....and there it was!  *sigh*  nostalgia.....

It's a nice park though.  Not too big and not too small.  I guess there's a part of the park where your doggies can roam around free, but uh I saw them in all parts so not sure where that area is?!   A lot of grassy areas to throw your blanket down and have a picnic or just lay out.  Great view of the painted ladies as well as the city skyline.  I wish I came here around sunset for the photo op.  Maybe next time!
author: Bernadette M.

description: Perfect view of San Francisco's famous Painted Ladies.
author: Rose A.

description:
Best park to enjoy an Ike's Place sandwich. 

The girl to guy tourist ratio is very high, so I rate it high on the pickup parks charts. 

Bathrooms have soap and seat covers, very clean, probably due to #1 in Rory H.'s review.
author: Luke H.

description:
I have to post this in the middle of the night in the hopes of avoiding the wrath of the SF crew.  Far be it from me to criticize a public park, but Alamo Square is way overrated.  It's just a big hill with grass and a few trees.  Oh, and a janky tennis court.  And a questionable restroom.  But that's it.

I never knew about the Full House connection until reading the little review blurbs along the right side as I write this.  Yeah, sorry guys--that is not a good enough reason for four or five stars.  San Francisco has some great, great parks; in fact it has the best large-scale parks in the country.  But Alamo Square is just a boring piece of land.  It's good for the same things that other parks are, which is a beautiful thing, but that just isn't enough.
author: David R.

description:
My favourite spot in SF. Just seat on the grass and enjoy the "painted ladies".

Mon spot préféré à SF. Asseyez vous sur l'herbe et comtemplez les "painted ladies"
author: Mark B.

description:
My favorite city park for a pic-a-nic and this is why:

1) Bums seem to lazily avoid the hills that form the perimiters.
2) Saggy trouser drug dealers prefer other less touristy parks.
2) Nice grass and gardens.
3) Awesome view of skyline and famous SF architecture.
4) Tourist watching at its best. How many random tourists have sat on the porches of the Painted Ladies for a photo op?
5) This is where Danny Tanner prefers to picnic.
author: R J.

description:
ATMOSPHERE:
This park has a good view of the city! And plus the Full House houses! (Painted Ladies) ^________^ 

Not only that but it has 

1.) Playground
2.) Tennis court
3.) Bathroom
4.) Nice Grassy Hills to lounge on
author: Angela L.

description:
Last night my neighborhood park evoked the feeling of NYC in the summer. At 10 pm, people were still milling about, parked on blankets, sipping wine under the stars, walking their dogs, and talking to neighbors. At that hour, it was still a balmy 80 degrees, a far cry from the usual wind-whipped meat freezer it becomes when the sun sets and the tour buses leave.

Whatever its incarnation, my local park rules and kicks Dolores Park's ass! Okay, maybe not. It can't compete with the sheer size, sun exposure, and various demographics (the gay banana hammock lawn on the southeast end, the gangbangers on the west lawn, or drug dealers, but for a little park it kicks butt.
author: Suzanne R.

description: Great FREE place to visit while in San Fran. Beautiful views and close access to other  sites
author: Marty B.

description: I love this dog park, it's nice and close to my house.  Lots of nice dogs and people too.  only bad thing is when it gets muddy the hills are terrible!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
As a dog-owner that lives nearby, this place has become my home away from home. We take our dog there 2-3 times a day and he gets to roam free in a pretty large off-leash dog area. The people that also take their dogs there seem great and responsible, which makes for happy dogs, happy dog owners and a clean park. Best part - there are NO squirrels to entice my furry companion to disappear.

As just a visitor sans furry companion, this park is very well kept (grass is green, trees are trimmed, etc) and offers great views. Large tour buses come regularly to schlep tourists to see the Painted Ladies. There is a deli/convenience store nearby (plus!) in case you wanted to have an impromptu picnic and it's perfectly situated along the Bay to Breakers route (plus! plus!).

Within the past year, they cleared out the a lot of the underbrush below the tall trees and in some other areas so that certain people and activities would be discouraged to stay. Turns out it worked!

Great place for families. There is a lovely playground area that is kept just as clean as the rest of the place. One tennis court is available (no lights for night-time though) nestled among the trees. There are also public restrooms available (but I'd leave those for the tourists).
author: Jasmyn M.

description: Full House. Why else would you come here? Maybe the view is beautiful too. It wasn't until I saw the 5-year engagement that I told myself I should come here. I brought my sister here as we grew up watching the show. It was pretty funny trying to figure out which house they lived in and which was Kimmy's. I feel sorry for whoever lives there, they must get bothered a lot from tourists and nostalgic people alike. It was pretty windy there, and definitely an uphill/downhill hike.
author: Phan H.

description:
I like to walk cities.  
I like to take mass transit.  
Getting your soles down with the sidewalks of a town is my preferred method for getting to know a place and making it mine.  

After exploring the Haight, I huffed it to a hill.  I wanted to meet some ladies....The Painted Ladies.

These Damsels of the Bay truly are a must see (even if they've been snapped, photo-ed, painted, etched, filmed, and written by many a person).  

I was lucky to make it here on an excellent-weather day.  Sure the Painted Ladies are the stars here, but there is so much more.  So, snap your pictures of the dolled up chicas, but be sure to explore this park.  This park is a green space with a small hill at its center.  At the peak, you will find a banos/loo/bathroom which was rockin' it's early 20th Century grandeur and was surprisingly clean---California budget woes???  I wouldn't know it from this spic 'n' span bathroom pit stop.

On the hill you have very tall and cool trees and shrubbery of many types.  Work them into your 360degrees of photo opportunities here.  People-watching also abounds here.  If you're a doggie lover, this park also serves you well with all sorts of mutts running with abandon in the sun on the green green grass.

Speaking of grass, I ended up parking myself on a patch and ended up pulling out my Don Quixote (Yeah, Cervantes has accompanied me to many places.  This book is my Sancho on my worldly adventures of slaying city serpents).  I tried to read a few pages, but as usual, my surroundings were too distracting.

Ok, this is my challenge for you.  I dare you to take a nap or read a book here.  

Go ahead.  

TRY IT!  

I assure you the distractions of this beautiful park, in this magnificent city, will slay you every time.
author: Corey G.

description: Walking up to the top will give your cardio a little boost.  Of course when we went, two of the homes were being painted or reno'd or something so we didn't get that 'classic' postcard look we hoped for the but view is still amazing even if all of the painted ladies were tented and not just two.
author: A. S.

description: Beautiful day today to enjoy the sun at AS. Spent time with the family on the grass and also at the kids playground - hidden behind the trees. Lol. Must visit if you're from out of town.
author: Karol S.

description: I had to check out this park coz of Full house! Omg! I was too overwhelmed! Just to sit and relax and feel nostalgic about full house! Loved it! cute lil houses they call Painted Ladies(no idea why) around! so damn cute!!!!
author: Sara S.

description: I've been here twice and the only reason why I come is to see the "Painted Ladies." If you're trying to get a good photo of the "Painted Ladies," the best time to come is after 3PM. The sun is on the correct side and you'll getting pretty decent lighting. If you come in the evening, on the opposite side of the "Painted Ladies" you can catch a really nice sunset.
author: Anna F.

description:
Really nice park, and it's big enough to get away from most of the tourists that stare at the Pained Ladies (Full House house) 
I can't wait for my puppy to be a little bit more reliable so I can let him off of his leash to play.
author: Amanda M.

description:
An AMAZING neighborhood park.

Scenic from all angles, historic, and a great place to have a picnic or just enjoy a drink in a beautiful place! This park always has great vibes and is an awesome place to bring your dog. If that's not enough, then go there to watch gobs of tourists do their best pose in front of the painted ladies. 

Bottom Line: Check this place out whenever the sun is shining, you will not be disappointed!
author: Kevin D.

description: Beautiful neighborhood park! Great views of The City,great dog area,nice tennis courts,& lovely place for a picnic. It can be windy at times,so bundle up if it's a chilly day.
author: Shelley M.

description: When Dolores Park is too crowded, when Golden Gate Park seems too far, Alamo Square is just right. Never too crowded, good place to let dogs run. Most important, the views of downtown are simply spectacular: the painted ladies framing the skyline.
author: Dustin B.

description: Famous for being on the title sequence of Full House, Alamo Square park offers much more than a photo op with the "Painted Ladies." It's also home to a dog park (no fence) and affords lovely views of the city. A great place to soak in some sun, or for tourists, to rest your feet and take a pee break (bathrooms are at the top of the hill). It can get super foggy of course, and the temp can drop rapidly, so if you're planning to stay around, bring lots of layers and maybe even a blanket.
author: Ana R.

description:
In typical SF fashion I came to Alamo Square park for some day time relaxing. 

With my packed lunch and a bottle of wine I sat there with some friends and just let myself be! Great thing to do every now and then. 

This park is awesome for a few reasons. 1) The painted ladies. They are really a staple of SF and I enjoy SF architecture. 2) Tons of fun people bring their dogs here to play fetch with. Being a huge dog person I really love this! and lastly / most importantly 3) I REALLY loved Full House as a child and this totally makes me happy to be in the park from the opening credits. 

YA and I even busted out my iphone to play the Full House theme song... Whew! I admitted it! 

Great part with an awesome view of not only the painted ladies but all of downtown SF!
author: Dawn N.

description: A fantastic park.  Full House memories will flood you as you overlook the Painted Ladies, and you get a beautiful panoramic view of the city.  The park itself is actually much bigger than I originally thought; there's a playground and pathways to walk through that makes you feel that you're taking a leave from the city life for awhile.  But, of course, still in the city.  :)  Wonderful spot to grab a coffee, read a book, or just take it all in.
author: Mel G.

description: A big green park on a sunny SF day is like finding a $20 in the pocket of your winter jacket. What a treat!
author: Grace L.

description: Cool park, for our kids it was a blast and our dog loved it too. Look forward to coming back.
author: Matt S.

description: Just knowing that I was going to go to see the famous Painted Ladies from the show Full House was satisfaction itself.  I was so giddy with anticipation going over the little hill on Steiner Street.  When I finally got sight of Alamo Square and the Painted Ladies I had died and gone to heaven.  Full House heavily influenced my childhood so it was so neat to finally see the famous opening scene in person.  On the day I went the weather was a bit cloudy so I didn't get a good view of the city behind the houses.  All in all...it was fun going!!!
author: Celin S.

description:
Damn it.  I just wrote a long review that got eaten.  Sorry if this is scatterbrained, but I'm angry right now.

This is one of the best parks in the world.  I won't bore you with all the details of why this is a fun park.  But I'll point out two things you probably don't know about Alamo Square.  Up by the bathrooms and tennis court, there are plants potted in different kinds of footwear.  The tradition is that when you move out of the neighborhood, you leave a pair of shoes or heels or ski boots for the groundskeeper to pot plants in.  I hope I won't be leaving my shoes for a long time.  They filmed part of Invasion of the Body Snatchers in the playground.  

This park makes me proud to live in San Francisco and this neighborhood.  I take it for granted, but it doesn't hold it against me.  It's also a nice place to take dogs and kids, preferably at the same time.

Oh, and I absolutely abhor Full House, but you people really did not watch your sitcoms very closely.  The opening of Full House has them picnicking in Alamo Square, but their house is not one of the Painted Ladies.  Their house is actually in the Marina or Cow Hollow or whatever.  It has a red door.  None of the Painted Ladies has a red door.
author: John S.

description: This is a gorgeous urban park - it's known for iconic views of a row of Victorian houses known as "Painted Ladies" with downtown San Francisco above in the background.  Great place to go have a picnic, read a book and enjoy the people and dog watching.  Bring a blanket or a chair because the grass/ground can often be damp.
author: Jenn C.

description:
yes yes, this is where the full house house is... so be prepared for lots of tour buses and people taking photos.

i love the dogs everywhere :)

there are tennis courts.

i came to lie down after walking around the city. nice place to just sit and chill. on a sunny day, it's bliss.

i also remember (slightly) doing my first beer bong here for bay to breakers a couple years ago wooooooohoooooooooo
author: Kailey O.

description:
Main reason I wanted to visit Alamo Square was 'cause of the Painted Ladies.  Second was 'cause of the view behind the Painted Ladies.  Third was 'Full House' (I'm a huge Olsen twins fan!).

Thankfully we arrived just before the sun set, around 5:00 pm, so we could still catch a couple of daytime photo ops.  Really, really beautiful and breathtaking views of the city behind the Painted Ladies.  I imagine those houses are really expensive since they're so well known.  But that's off-topic.  

Alamo Square is definitely a must-see in San Francisco!
author: Ivy W.

description:
Day three of our vacation GBF#1 and I knew we wanted to head out to Richmond for some dim sum so on our way there we made a pit stop at Alamo Square just to see the lavish Victorian cookie cutter houses and some painted ladies.  

We arrived early in the day and the park was filled with people walking their dogs.  OMG so many dogs, some cute, some ugly, some big, some small but so many out having a grand old time in the sun and grass and very little poop on the ground.  The park also has a pretty big play ground for the little ones to play on and if I remember correctly tennis courts too.  

Besides the houses, the dogs, the playground and the grass Alamo Square also has some amazing views of downtown San Francisco and thankfully we were there on a very clear day so we could see for miles around.  Oh and I guess I should add something about Full House and the Tanners to make it complete so there I mentioned them.
author: Me H.

description: It can be a bit of a tourist-trap, but it's a great spot to hang out with your pooch.
author: M R.

description:
A good friend of mine lived at Steiner and Wall. Another one of my besties lived at Page and Pierce. Collectively they lived in that neighborhood for more than a decade and a half and never once did we even venture out to Alamo Square. 

However, one day, on the way home, BA and I decided to stop the car and picnic because the sun was shining and we just happened upon that rare parking space. I remember it vividly, we had Mediterranean. The memory is a brief but a good one. Sigh. I wish we had more than just that one afternoon there. RIP BA.
author: Chum L.

description:
If you're visiting San Francisco, Alamo Square is one of those places that you must "check in" to and check off your list! Such a beautiful view of San Francisco and the "Painted Ladies"!!! Once you park and walk up the hill, the theme song from FULL HOUSE automatically plays in your head. 

TIP: Drive a couple blocks down to Broderick and take a picture in front of the house! 

Great picture of SF, great place to let your dog run free, nice park to have a picnic!!! Restroom was a little dirty but what park restroom is nice and clean? Parking is horrible (as always). So Drive by on your way to PIer 39 and Lombard St!
author: Sara N.

description:
Ahh Ahh Ahh Ahh Chity Chi bob botta.....sing it Uncle Jesse!

If you need to fill the void that was left when Full House went off the air, if the nostalgia of TGIF and simpler times are what you are searching for, this is where all things become right in your world again. 

The park itself is beautiful, well kept, and not just a tourist destination but one frequented by the locals as well. The views from the top of the sloping square are amazing and were well worth the little hike we made from our hotel in Union Square.

There are many parts of San Francisco that I did not have a chance to take in on my short visit, one intriguing bit would have to be this shoe garden that everyone talks about and posts pictures of. If that's not reason enough to get back to the west coast then I don't know what is.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
San Francisco never disappoints.  I've visited the city nearly 50 times and although I can no longer visit the Fisherman's Wharf - might just puke into my mouth if I went there again - I haven't had the exposure to see different neighborhoods of this city.

The Alamo Square is a terrific little hill top located in the Fillmore neighborhood.  The park itself has a nice tennis court.  I love how the tennis courts in San Francisco are always located at these perfect places.  (remember the tennis courts at the Presidio?)  No tennis player is really looking at the view while actually concentrating on the ball, but there is a certain aesthetic appeal to having a tennis court perched on the top of a hill, with Victorian residences in the foreground and almost every sightable sight in the background.

The dog park is a wonderful little patch of land, and even though I don't have a dog myself and don't even live in San Francisco, I wish I'd one day be a pet owner, playing with his pet on top of this park.  

One must mention the Painted Ladies.  If you're into architecture history, make sure you check out the painted ladies from the park, especially when the sun is hitting just the roof tops.  A mix of Victorian style houses and Edwardian style houses, both truly dating back to the time that these styles existed.  

The romance of San Francisco is fully appreciated in the Alamo square area.  Views ranging from downtown to twin peaks and everything in between, put this hill top as one of my favs, ahead of Nob Hill too.
author: Aditya R.

description:
When I come to Alamo Square only 2 things come to mind:
1) Full House 
2) the amazing view of the skyline!

I've lived in the Bay for most of my life and I had never been here until recently. And I literally discovered that day that the view was that amazing. I had no idea that it was where Postcard Row was! I just knew it was where the Painted Ladies were (why that connection never clicked in my head I will never know lol). 

It's pretty cool that even though it's kind of far away from Downtown, it's high enough on the hill where you can just see the buildings in FiDi peek out over the roofs of the Painted Ladies.

Anyway, though it is a tourist spot due to the Painted Ladies, it is in no way super touristy like Fisherman's Wharf and that's exactly the way I like it. A good mix of locals and tourists, just like the Golden Gate Bridge and the Embarcadero areas. 

It is a bit of a pain to get there just because of the hills you gotta climb whether you're walking or driving. Parking is a bit scary if you're not used to the hills. 

Nevertheless, it's well worth a visit, especially if you're a 90s kid like me and you watched Full House religiously.
author: Constance C.

description: One of my favorite places to go to in San Francisco. I love it here. Just strolling around and people watching is fun. Can't walk away without a picture in front of the Painted Ladies. Beautiful!
author: Rebekah S.

description: Great park! Love walking around with my shoes off and strolling in this wonderful yet hilly park! The views are spectacular, the ambiance fantastic; they even have a playground for the little ones. I just love coming here and yes, I found myself taking pics of this wonder. Historic area and a hop skip and a jump to anywhere in the city. Great park to have a picnic with friends and special loving people as well.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Please don't pee in Alamo Square anymore.

My first memory of Alamo Square is when I went walking in SF and happened upon a Shoe Garden. Then closely followed a walking tour group to realize I was in the famous park with the "houses from that one TV show" I was discovered by the tour guide when I yelled out "Full House". He shooed me away. ::smile::

My second memory is when I passed by Alamo Square during Bay to Breakers only to see that my favorite Shoe Garden was being pee-ed upon by many drunken citizens. This made me sad. How would you like it if the Shoe Garden pee-ed on you? Huh! 

That is all.
author: Cat R.

description: True to city-dwelling form, I relish open park spaces, lying out on the grass, and just watching the world go by. Yes, Alamo Square Park is right next to the Painted Ladies, they are beautiful, yes. But this park is also a really lovely spot to sit and watch puppies and look over the other city vistas. Listen to the wind rustle through the cypress and eucalyptus trees. Bring a book and a jacket. Watch the clouds go by.
author: Mea H.

description:
Alamo Square is a very nice (hilly) park located across from the world famous "Painted Ladies". I must warn you that it is a few steps to get to the top of the park and the only true way to take in the view of the city and the Painted Ladies is from the top (worth the climb).

Parking can be tought since it is a popular tourist stop so prepare to drive awhile around the park before finding a parking spot. 

Simply a must stop especially on your first visit to SF.

*Insert Full House theme song here*
author: Saul A.

description:
Unlike the other bashers who think Alamo Square is for the foreign folks - I think this is a lovely place to relax for a few even if you are from here. Maybe even snap a picture or two; even though I've already done it a million times -it's just what you do!

A lovely place in a lovely city. I always laugh about the 7th "step-sister" the one on the left...it looks a bit out of place.

Take Note: This is NOT the location of the Full House house.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Full house houses! Cute park. Well maintained. Love that I can always find parking around here!
author: Leana L.

description:
i was here for one thing only... take a pic in front of the "FULL HOUSE" scene. yup that's it! another item done on my things to do before i die. 

well i'll just say that it is very pretty.. i can just picture myself having a picnic here. It was quiet, the weather was nice - you got the sun and the cool breeze from the bay, the view was gorgeous. I wish i can bike around here everyday.
author: Cherie T.

description:
Love taking the dogs here! People are really responsible with their dogs and I love that the dogs can go leash free. Also a great spot for a picnic with the pup and to show tourists. 

Clean and a great view of the city!
author: Kellie N.

description:
If you're a tourist, come here for the Full House houses and the view. If you're a resident, come here for the dog park and the noticeable lack of  compared to other parts. In other words, no matter who you are, come here. 

Don't count on parking; I live on this block and it's often rough. Take the 21 Hayes or 5 Fulton or the 24 Divisadero or the 22 Fillmore.
author: Steve G.

description: Maybe it was the prospect of living a block away from here. Maybe it was the 4505 meat in tube form to my face. Maybe it was the sunshine. Maybe it was the mutts running amok in a good way. Maybe it was the gal on my shoulder. Maybe it's the idea of Stamos & Saget getting tipsy and tumbling down these knolls at 3am rehashing their mullet-ed past. There are so many reasons that lead to adding all the parts of this park up for it to take the top spot of the highly competitive SF Parks. Golden Gate is a village of itself, and really special, almost so much it's on a list of itself. But the other urban parks in neighborhoods: Dolores, Duboce, Lafayette, Alta, Precita. They're all special. Some not even mentioned. But here. Man. Views, space, benches, dogs, dog space for off leash, woods, and central location. There won't likely be pot truffles, riotous tents being posted up for impromptu concerts, and you won't feel like you're on the school ground recess park like Dolores. You're also likely not to be hassled by any street life asking for change or newspapers to blot away their urine on their pants. This park restores some faith in a civil city. It really makes for a weekend destination. A weekday relaxation break. A reason to walk and rest. Like the Alamo, preserve this space.
author: Jon A.

description: This place is NOT a dog park; it's a park you can take your dog to play off leash and that's as good as it gets. Surrounded by busy streets, tour buses and people everywhere,  dogs must have excellent recall and voice control which makes this a great place for a family outing with Fido.
author: Mark I.

description:
Painted Ladies. Shoe gardens. Transamerica Pyramid views. Twin Peaks glimpses. Plenty of grass to relax on while taking it all in.

As the tour buses roll by and the tourists snap pictures of one of the most quintessential spots of our mighty fine city, you gotta think some secretly want to call this magical place home. So glad we do.
author: Jason B.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco for 26 years and the beauty of  this city still blindsides me at random moments.  I  ride by Alamo Square and the Painted Ladies on the 21 Hayes every single day on my way downtown.  And each morning I have the priveledge of stopping to think, "Is this my life?  Do I really live here?  Is this city really mine?"

After all this time, the magic didn't fade.  I will never move to Walnut Creek.
author: Kerry D.

description: Buster loves to root around in the grass here amongst the city views. Great place for pooches!
author: Laura F.

description: Great park. There are constantly people just hanging out, sitting in the grass, having picnics. A ton of fun and great views of the city. A lot of dog owners visit as well. The park is super clean, though!!
author: Chris D.

description: Another great San Francisco park with unbelievable views of the city. This park is very dog friendly as you can see when you walk around the place. However, the hills are tiring when you walk around so much. The painted ladies provide a nice picture perfect postcard for any snapshot and it is where the Full House gang would play around on some days. There is an interesting shoe garden in the park which cracks me up when I actually saw it in person. The park can get windy at times but that would not stop me to enjoy the great views of this great city. I took my date here and we both created some wonderful pictures in which I cannot wait to show them!
author: Danster L.

description:
whatever happened to predictibility..the milkman, the paper boy, the evening tv..Everywhere you look, everywhere you go (theres a heart), Theres a heart. 
A hand to hold onto.
Everywhere you look , everywhere you go.
There's a face
Of somebody who needs you.
Eveywhere you look,
When you're lost out there and you're all alone,
A light is waiting to carry you hooooommmeee. 
Everywhere you look.
Everywhere you look. 

Sit down and have a picnic in alamo square...full house family style.
author: Daniella B.

description:
Painted Ladies, Clean Grass, Open Space and Great People.  What more could I ask for in a park?   

It's not as crowded or loud as Dolores Park.  Definitely a park to sit and read or relax with a group of friends.
author: Morgan L.

description: Cute place to take a photo from memories of Full House
author: Tay T.

description: Alamo Square is one of my favorite places in the city. Why? For one thing, on a nice and clear day you can see an awesome view of the city skyline from here. Another reason is that it reminds me of the tv show Full House, which I watched a lot as a kid. Just seeing the opening credits and catching a view of Alamo Square and the Painted Ladies always got me excited.
author: Frances V.

description:
Living in San Francisco, I have found it easy to get burned out on touristy locales.  When guests come into town and I ask them what they want to see- I typically dread the answers to come.  It isn't that I do not appreciate entities such as Fisherman's Wharf and Alcatraz for their history and uncanny ability to produce tourist revenue for the city.  It is just that, these places are not San Francisco to me.  Not the San Francisco that I know and love.  

So, I will take my guests wherever they would like to go.  But since I am fortunate enough to live two blocks from Alamo Square, it is easy for me to ask them to go on an impromptu walk up the street at sunset.  As we walk through the park they too begin to understand what makes this place so special.  

The views from Alamo Square juxtapose the old Victorian Painted Ladies with the modern Financial District and a perfectly painted California sky in the background.  Sometimes I come here-  just stare and think..."I'm not in Michigan anymore, thank goodness."

As an everyday venue, this is a great park to take your dog off-leash or go for a run yourself.  There is a nice playground and plenty of benches for taking in the views.  

I took off one star because the tennis courts really need to be worked on.  I live close by, but will never play here on these cracked courts.
author: Floyd R.

description: This place is amazing, a great relaxing place on a sunny day to soak up the sun and a beautiful view of the city's skyline. It's not necessarily a close walk, but it's totally worth the walk. Plan to come here more often when I'm in town. Tends to be sunny when I'm in town.
author: Anshel S.

description:
Looking for a place to visit on a trip to SF?  Check this out!

You'll see the "Full House" house and a very cool view of the city.  The park is in close proximity to the Haight and Hayes Valley.  It's also about a 20 minute walk from City Hall.  

I love the local neighborhood feel with all the people laying out on the grass and playing ball with the dog.  Also, don't miss the shoe garden.   It's a very bohemian, fun idea.  It inspires me to make one one day.

Fun times!  Get your booty out ot the house and get over there.
author: Alexis B.

description: Nice little park to bring the doggies to and get a view of the painted ladies. A lot of people come here to take pictures of them. There are a few benches and tables to sit and talk and enjoy things at. This is just another place that I like to people watch or even to watch cars struggle to park in small spaces. I watched a car the other day that took ten minutes and then gave up and drove away. It was interesting.
author: Rachel W.

description: Alamo Square is definitely a landmark of San Francisco. Go there to visit the famous Painted Ladies featured in Full House. On any given day, you'll see tourists taking pictures with the houses and lounging on the grass on a sunny day. The only thing I didn't like about Alamo Square was the smell...there's a certain stink that lingers in the air. Other than that, it's beautiful - there's dogs playing on the grass, people people-watching, and tourists taking pictures.
author: Gina T.

description: This is a cool tourist spot or a local place to chill especially with your doggy! I went on a weekday so it was very empty and not overly crowded. The park is cool to walk or run through because of it's hills. The famous line of houses shown on Full House is pretty spectacular, see my photo!
