All in all, a cool place to chill, bring a blanket and layer... the sun gets you warm but normally there's a breeze!
author: Laura F.

description: Great little dog park with an amazing view of the SF skyline next to the painted ladies. There are plenty of cute little doggies who also pee and poo on the grass. Makes you wonder when you sit on the grass. I would give this park another star but I have 5 mosquito bites. =[
author: Sarah C.

description: Great place to lounge around on a lazy weekend afternoon if you don't want all of the pressure of trying to act cool at Dolores Park (I'm kidding). It's really amusing to see everyone oriented toward the Painted Ladies, but I guess Fullhouse nostalgia is one of the main draws to this park. It's a clean park with a good view, and pretty easy to get to -- worth checking out at least once.
author: Adam D.

description:
Full house point baby!! great place to chill out with some awesome views, some decent wine and some toilet paper so you can pee in the bushes.

i was hanging out with some friends and two dogs came over to us.  asked the owner their names...Jesse and joey...no sh*t, perfect way to wrap up an alamo park day.
author: kiki b.

description:
This park is great if you can make it up the hills.  The view of the "Painted Ladies" Victorian houses is awesome as well as the view into downtown.  It is off-leash dog friendly too.  I've spent afternoons reading, soaking up a little sun from this little haven.

Times visited: 4
author: Amy L.

description:
FULL HOUSE! My childhood show!!

Of course we had to stop here on our trip to SF. There's a park right in front of the painted ladies so it makes for a  a great photo op/tourist spot. Also a nice place to have a picnic or bring your family/pets. =)
author: Leanne D.

description:
Beautiful park.  I take my friends there who have never been there before.  I have gotten drunk and smoked park there at night with a bunch of graffiti writer friends also.  I show people the Miss Doubtfire house there.

Another SF treasure.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
"When you're lost out there, and you're all alone, a life is waiting to carry you home, Every where you look...."

This was our first stop during our trip to SF with friends. Great park filled with trees. Tons of places to sit, plenty of benches and of course grass - perfect for picnics. There's a tennis court hidden among the trees right along one of the paths too. Great view of the Painted Ladies and the SF skyline.
author: Irma E.

description:
Four facts about Alamo Square Park, based on my experience:

1. Epic and euphoric views of the city.

2. It's a dog party.

3. I lived at the corner of Scott and Fulton, next to the monster Victorian mansion.

4. The Painted Ladies are pretty zexy.
author: Valerie L.

description: If you liked the Full House sitcom, then take a picture at the Alamo Square.
author: Carlene R.

description: There one word I call this place! """""""""""AWESOME"""""""""" and if you have pets this is a great to meet friends here! Beautfull homes here and TONS of Pretty Ladys (I means Victora Homes near by) near by! Parking on the other hand not so much. Better off take a bus to come here!
author: EdwardF A.

description:
Strange name, sweet place!

(It's hard NOT to love a park that encompasses a famous vantage point of the epic, beautiful Painted Ladies....) 

Somehow we always manage to find a parking spot on the street w/ relative ease, too. 

This gorgeous park provides not only the aforementioned photo op but also one of City Hall which is equally as epic! 

- Aside from views of said awesomeness, this is a decent sized park with both trees & open grass that is perfect for laying around in and reading a book.

Surrounded by bustling neighborhoods and frequented by tourists, you're sure to always have an interesting (and memorable) experience at this neat gem!
author: Kai S.

description: This is my favorite park in San Francisco and a perfect place for laying out on a warm, sunny day! Spectacular views from the top of the park that span the vast SF skyline! And the Painted Ladies: gorgeous!
author: Rob L.

description: Excellent restaurant! Superb food and wine and the owner, Andre, is the best! The flourless chocolate is to die for as well!
author: Ellen M.

description: Came here to see the Full House tourist spot but was greatly disappointed. The park was very dead/mellow.
author: Angela L.

description: You need to stop here at least once to get a nice view of the Painted Ladies, and then you can also relax on the benches/lawn with a snack. Fairly quiet when we went and peaceful.
author: Aly M.

description:
I came at such a bad time when I visited the famous Painted Ladies. It was early evening and The sun was kinda low, so bad pictures of the painted Ladies... Plus My friends and I only stuck to the south side of the park. I wanted to go to see more of the park but it was getting cold in the middle of August, so it's off to home we go.

However next time, I'm going to explore the entire park! *crackles evilly*
author: Matt M.

description: The park in the Alamo Square area is really nice and has the accent of a grassy incline as viewed from the approach of Golden Gate Avenue.  While proceeding through this neighborhood, one might see any of the great features of the homes painted with different colors, different marquis buildings and churches, and any number of "pit stops" one can make in the area.  The area, given the particular location, also has excellent views of downtown.  Really nice!
author: Thomas H S.

description: Such a beautiful place to have a picnic! Amazing views and lots of room to spread out and picnic, play games and take the kids!
author: Mrs. B.

description:
Oh Alamo Square Park. I have to admit, the only reason I knew about it was due to having a secret love for Full House. However, that was not the sole reason I was headed there on a gorgeous afternoon the day I arrived in San Francisco. After grabbing some sustenance I trekked what seemed like a million miles uphill with my two carry-ons to spend a few relaxing hours at the park. 

I really love the view. I admit, this is the only park in SF I've been to, but it was beautiful. The painted ladies are gorgeous to look at not even including the rest of the view. I only hit one small area of the park, but from what I saw it was relatively clean and peaceful. I had a chance to read, listen to some music, and people watch. 

Until the Full House crazies arrived. All of them. Then I spent an hour and a half overhearing conversations debating which house they lived in (the answer of course is none since their house was a *set*) and the playing of the opening credits over and over again on you tube while debating this epic situation. 

There was construction going on behind me and fences were up which made me sad. I would've loved to see what else the park had to offer.
author: Tonia B.

description:
This is what happens when you stand around here long enough:

Tourists 1: "Can you take our picture in front of, you know, the tourist thing?"

Me: "Sure"

Tourists 2: "Can you take our picture in front of, you know, the tourist thing?"

Me: "Sure"

Tourists 3: "Can you talk dirty to us like Bob Saget in real life?

Me: "Sur....excuse you?!?" 

Doesn't this park just makes you want to sing the "Full House" theme in your head (or in my case, aloud and look like an authentic SF crazy)? 

La, la, la, laaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa Everywhere you look , everywhere you go (there's a heart). There's a heart A hand to hold onto....
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ul2QTLpasDs

Besides the Painted Ladies, don't forget to check out the shoe garden!
author: Kenny L.

description: Great place for a picnic with friends, family, or a significant other! You get wonderful views of the Painted Ladies and behind them, the skyline of SF!
author: Michelle L.

description: Apparently on MLK Day all the bars in the Divis corridor close so fortuitously for us, plan B was to grab some beers and head over to Alamo Square Park. How is it that I have lived in the city for this long and never spent an afternoon here? I felt sort of sorry for all the people on the tour buses that kept coming by. It must be torturous to be on a vehicle that stops only long enough to snap the key tourist picture of the Painted Ladies and the SF skyline instead of lounging on blankets, playing with random dogs, drinking beer and making friends in a city you love living in.
author: Jane K.

description:
Friend from out of town: Hey Jeff, take me to the Full House Park in SF.
Me: Don't be silly, that's just a TV show, that park doesn't exist.
Friend takes me to the Google.
Me: Well I'll be damned.

I was actually excited to see this place, I was looking forward to singing the theme song and running through the field. Except I forgot the lyrics when I was here so it was more like:

Everywhere you look, everywhere you go (there's a heart)
There's a heart.
I something something something **inaudible mumbling**

When you're lost out there and you're all alone.
Something is waiting... to carry you home!

Needless to say it didn't play out like it did in my head.

Anyone else think that Becky was hot?

I think I smell "Talk Thread".
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
So, I'm rewriting my review of Alamo Square...leaving it an awesome 5 stars...but my view on my neighborhood park has changed for the better since becoming a dog owner.

I've been stressing unnecessarily for a while now.....about life, love, money, just general stuff...but I've found the best therapist.  Its the dog park.  I go, take the pooches, and sit back and watch the interactions of this huge community of dogs.  On nice days the park is packed, and you can usually find a friend....for your dog.  Its awesome.  Most of the dog owners don't even talk to each other.  They admire one another's dogs, and see who sniffs whose butt, and who wants to play.  Just watching makes me super calm.  With my ipod on, nothing else matters.  It is a very zen place for me...and I'm glad its only a few blocks away.

And a side note.  Calm environments, such as the chaos of the dog park are very therapeutic...but you know what else is?  Having sex to heavy metal.  I would NOT recommend doing that in Alamo Square, ...but even if you aren't a metal fan...try it, you might like it.  The chaos is the therapy...gets you out of your own head...even if just for the length of the CD.



---------------------------------------------------
Original Review 12.05.06

What ever happened to predictability?  The milkman, the paperboy, and even MTV?  I have sung this song one too many times.  Something about the painted ladies inspires me....
Dog friendly park.
Picnic friendly park.
Full-house friendly park
author: Lauren F.

description:
Yesterday my friend and I grabbed our rackets and headed over to Alamo Square for a tennis match. There's only one tennis court and it's dead as a doorknob, but it's impossible not to feel soulfully alive in this park. 

The views are simply stunning, and I had forgotten how good it feels to sit in the playground on swinging tires and shoot the shit while pulling sweaters tightly and staring up at the tall trees all around.

I first saw Alamo Square in the movie Tales of the City when Mrs. Madrigal falls in love with a dying man. I feel a little bit like her sometimes. Minus the sex change, of course.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Yes this is where the "Full House" painted ladies can be seen.  

Yes I did the Dave Coulier "Cut.It.Out" bit for the camera when I first visited.  

No I did not see the actual "Full House" house here.  I'm beginning to think that was just a Hollywood set.  

Yes I've seen every episode of "Full House."  Probably more than once.  

No I don't think the Olsen twins are hot.   I watched those girls grow up on that show.  That's disgusting.
author: William S.

description: If you watched Full House growing up, you'll definitely want to visit this park. It's simple and nice and parking is tough!!!
author: Kaycie Y.

description: Nice place to take the pup. A tad windy, and watch out for the mud
author: E T.

description:
Hahaha, I love tourists!

And I realize that since I am an LA resident and a visitor to SF, that technically makes me a tourist, BUT I do work for an SF company and run with the locals, so I think that exonerates me from nerdy tourist status, okay?

Good. So Alamo Square. It's gorgeous. There are happy puppies running around and playing. Cute guys running around after the happy puppies and playing and this square is just a beautiful slice of SF life. It's also adjacent to the Full House houses. And this is where you lose me.

Why in God's name would this be a tourist destination? You do realize, the guy on the show had a mullet, right? You do realize there were creepy twins on that show, right? You do realize that the goofus comedian on there was rumored to be the guy who Alanis Morissette angrily scratches her nails down someone else's back to get over, right? You do realize that in real life Bob Saget is about the dirtiest bird around, right?

Wow, i think i actually just realized why this is a tourist destination. Nevermind.
author: Stephy S.

description:
I used to drive by this park all time going home from work. Oddly enough, I almost worked right by this park. And of course who can forget that this is the sight of the very famous Painted Ladies as seen in the all time family favorite sitcom Full House. Of course I've seen it from a number of angles and never seem to get it just right like the tv...oh well. 

I sometimes walked all the way here from Geary and just enjoy the park. It was rather peaceful despite the pain in the ass grade of the sloping landscape.
author: John-Michael C.

description:
What ever happened to predictability? 
The milk man, the paper boy, evening TV 
You miss your old familiar friends, but 
waiting just around the bend. 

Everywhere you look (everywhere) 
There's a heart (there's a heart) 
A hand to hold on to. 
Everywhere you look (everywhere) 
There's a face of somebody who needs you. 

When you're lost out there and your all alone 
A light is waiting to carry you home 
Everywhere you look. 

Yeah so most of known references of San Francisco were from the show "Full House" and the movie "The Rock". 

So sure enough we made our way over to check out the Painted ladies, (houses from full house) 

It wasn't as spectacular as I remembered from a child. 

Maybe it's because mary-kate and ashley are all grown up and cause as much drama as paris hilton that makes this place just not as cool as I imagined it would be. 

SKIP!!!
author: David N.

description:
Beautiful park, and yesterday, even hosted a Rocket Dog adoption fair!   The weather was sunny and lots of really nice people came by to see the dogs. There was a flea market too, but I did not find anything worth spending a dollar on. 
My friend bought one of those old school popcorn machines.  Oh, and my favorite purchase.  A sign that said "welcome" with a big cow underneath.  Nothing says welcome quite like a cow, I always say.  Everyone should hang a cow on their front door, I think there would be a lot less violence on the streets.
If you have a dog, or just want to enjoy the sun, this park is worth a trip. 

Insert Full House reference here.
Dammit, I had to.
author: Starla D.

description: So I visited San Francisco and was on a trolley tour cart. The guide took us anywhere that we wanted to go and I exclaimed, "FULL HOUSE AREA!!!!" Thank goodness he knew exactly what I was talking about and even told us that the park is called Alamo (Almo) Square! Took great photos, had a lot of fun rolling down the hills, took some photos in our "Full House" poses, and reminisced on good ol' Full House days. And yes, I know this area was famous before the TV show but if I want to pretend that I was Michelle Tanner, then darn it.. I will. Lol :P
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
I am lazy.  Which means it probably wasn't the greatest idea for me to get a dog.  Nevertheless, I got one anyway.  And apparently, he requires ridiculous things like "walks" and "food."  Keeping things alive is hard work.

Alamo Square makes that a little easier.  I start my mornings off at the park, admiring the view of downtown and the Bay, and occasionally smirking at tourists.  My dog likes the pee on everything there.  He once attempted to pee on a tourist's leg, but that's a story for another day.  

Even though I love my neighborhood park, there are a couple of things that drive me nuts (hence the minus-one-star): homeless people who eat chicken wings and leave their chicken bones behind in the dog park; irresponsible dog owners who don't clean up poo;  children (I like dogs, not children); and that damn puddle!  

Otherwise, though, it's a great place to have a picnic on a sunny day, take a stab at learning tennis, or run around with your four-legged friends.
author: Jess T.

description:
Fear of the unknown or a more reasonable fear of the Western Addy keeps many away from this little gem.  

This park employs a modern "green" hipster repellent -- the hill.  Through this modern marvel, there's nary a fixed gear bike to be seen.

There is no better way to spend a relaxing afternoon than drinking in public and few better public places to drink than Alamo Square.  

If you look close enough you may find an Olsen twin walking hand-in-hand with Dave Coulier.
author: jack p.

description:
I know everyone likes to come here because it gets shown in the opening credits of Full House, but I don't find anything particularly enchanting about this place. 

That's not to say it's not a cool place to hang out. This is the closest park to me, so I come here all the time. I walk up, sit and enjoy the view while meeting some of SF's finest furry friends. And hopefully their not-so-furry owners as well.

However I still miss living by Golden Gate Park.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Ahhhh, my neighboring gorgeous Alamo Square Park holds the most memories of any place in this magical city. It's as significant as a certain ungrassy park in AZ, the location of my very 1st makeout...friends gazing, vying with a stopwatch, as I tested the elasticity of my braces' rubberbands. That park came to hold so many more 1sts-chewing tobacco, underage drinking, grapefruit fights, being arrested, etc etc...Good parks make for good times, right?

Alamo Square is my SF version.
It's been a place to start, end, explode, burn-out, test, ignite, and close so many relationships. Each spot: shoe garden, tennis court, park bench, doggie grounds, and the Full House viewing hill, have connections. Don't get me wrong, ASP is awesome for drawing, BBQ-ing, and napping too. It's just so much more than a giant hill-park.
It's a place were the bad, ugly, but mostly really good stuff happens...
author: Nicole L.

description: Came here on a super rainy day .. just to see the painted ladies and take pictures of the great views of the city. I wish I could have stayed longer to enjoy the park, but it was pouring. It seems to be a really nice park .. great for picnics and kids to play. PLUS ... the views are beautiful!
author: Emily P.

description: I love this park.  I bring my dogs here all the time.  There is a good loop you can walk on and one side has an area where dogs are allowed off leash.  The other side is the one that stays sunny.  Sometimes this park is windier than others but i still love it.  Also, there are always tourists checking out the great view of the painted ladies.
author: Julie B.

description:
First things first: this is the home of the Painted Ladies (the row of 6 Victorian houses that you always see on the postcard), and it is also featured in the Full House intro.  (But note that the actual house from Full House is *not* on Alamo Square, it's up near Broderick & Bush).

But touristo-cultural references aside, Alamo Square is one of the best "square" parks in the city, perched atop a hill with nearly 360 views of the city.  These views come in very handy on 4th of July, as it's a very convenient place to watch the fireworks (ie, you can actually park nearby).  There's a sizeable crowd but still plenty of room to sit down.  Some of the fireworks are blocked by Russian Hill, (which makes it look like the city is being bombed), but overall you get a great show.  People were ironically chanting "USA! USA!", and others not-so-ironically counter-chanting "Stop the war!"...good ol' SF.

I'll have to come back in the daytime to explore further (and particularly to see the shoe garden), but it's clearly a well-maintained park, and one of those classic spots that every good city-dweller should visit at some point.
author: Wes M.

description: Another San Francisco tourist landmark. The 6 Victorian houses that make up the Painted Ladies is more for those who appreciate art and architecture. The colors and designs are pretty but i dont think this attraction would keep my attention compared to palace of fine arts and Lombard street. Its also a park and might be a decent place for a picnic but not one of the best of the best tourist attractions IMO in san francisco.
author: Robert Y.

description:
I love living near this park. When I take the 21 bus home I get off on Hayes & Pierce and cut through the park to get home. It's a great view at the very top and there's almost always a dog owner playing with their dog around. I live vicariously through my friends with dogs so it's always nice to see!

I want to make use of the tennis courts here, too
author: Brianna H.

description:
It's always a must-see attraction whenever I have out of town guests visit me. 

They've always asked me where this row of Painted Ladies are in the City and well, to their surprise, I'll take them there without notice. 

A smile is a thousand words...unsaid. And that..my friends, I'd rather see their smiles than hearing a "Thank you."
author: Mika D.

description:
Kinda on the dead side but you get the perfect view of the Painted Ladies (aka the houses in Full House tv show) ... across the street.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Do the houses near the square look familiar? It's 'cause they're the Full House houses! Too bad when I came here it was too dark to take pictures in front of the tv landmark :(
There was nothing much to look at around here. Alamo Square is just a park so I guess if you like parks then this is a good place for you.
author: Lisa T.

description: The hills around and through Alamo Square are my own personal stair-stepper with a view.  I run circles around you, square.
author: Katie S.

description: This was seriously awesome.  I've watched every episode of Full House at least 5 times so seeing this was a historical moment, for me at least.  Embarrassingly enough, the bf and I even took out his iPhone so we could listen to the theme song and see if the colors of the houses have changed.  I wonder if the residents (are there any?) mind that people are just sitting there staring at their houses.  No wonder all the curtains are pulled shut.  I brought my dog here and let him run around off-leash which was great because all the other dogs were running freely too!  On a sunny day, I would like to bring a blanket and sleep out on the poop-infested but very green grass. How can you beat beautiful Victorian houses with the SF skyline in the back? Perfect!
author: Shannon L.

description:
Update: 2/17/2008

As of the 1st of February, we've moved away from Alamo Square, and we miss the park fiercely.

What many folks don't say in their reviews is that the dog park community there is an amazing set of fantastic people who love their pups and take great interest in their community. 

It was here that the boy teamed up with another dog owner to surreptitiously fill up a stanky, foetid sinkhole of muddy rank water - sure giardia for dogs who drink it... 

It was here that we got a connection to the lead attorney on Ellis evictions at the Tenderloin Housing Clinic who happens to walk his dog through the park.  The attorney was one of the best resources we had during that horrible time...

The boy (to another dog owner): "I don't suppose you'd know anything about Ellis evictions?"
Dog owner: "Not really - but you should really talk to [attorney] ... hey he lives over there and it looks like his light is on... you could knock on his door..."
The boy: ok, thanks...
Dog owner: "Oh wait... here he comes walking up the path with his dog Milo right now!"

I know this above narration is a bit random but, some 2 weeks after moving, we definitely miss the dog park here and the other dog owners.


========================
2/23/2007
Since puppy, I've been ever so grateful for the big, beautiful, hilly expanse of The Alamo, just a block away from our front door.

The Puppy Playground is on the crest of one of the windiest hills in the city, and even though she always comes back filthy with mud and other doggies' slobber, it's truly worth it for the hard romps that tire her out for the rest of the day.

I love the tiny little doggie water fountain low and convenient, the ever-so-romantic SF skyline, all sparkly glittery at night.
author: Claudine C.

description:
Where is the Full House house?

It's not here in Alamo Square as believed by many.  It's really located here:  1709 Broderick Street, near Bush Street. In the opening credits, the Tanner family picnics in Alamo Square.  Ah, the power of tv.

Still, the site is well worth a visit if you've never been.  Enjoy the painted ladies and visit the park.  Watch tourists huddle for that Kodak snapshot.  Find a small mocked up painted ladies facade on the play structure. Enjoy the wind and view of SF. Find the hidden shoe garden.  But let 'em know the real Full House is...about 12 blocks away.
author: Jen L.

description: Great attraction for tourists! The famous houses remind me of Full House and Family Matters (shows I used to watch all the time when I was younger). Great place to have a picnic and enjoy the scenery. The actual Full House house (Tanner Residence) is down the street!
author: Cindy L.

description: I always march my out-of-town visitors up to this park. And they are always filled with awe.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Easy to find, plenty of neighborhood parking...or it was just our lucky day. 

This area was beautiful. It's a dog park + tennis court + picnic area + a good walk. 

My boyfriend & I came here on a Sunday morning 11am-noonish (after a night of partying), and relaxed here. There were benches in many areas of the park, and we dog-watched, people-watched, and observed the views of San Francisco (since the park was on a hill). 

Lots of areas of shades or sunlight and surrounded by the houses you see on Full House. It was lovely ! =)
author: Sonya T.

description:
My favorite house in the city sits on the corner of Fulton and Scott, at the northwest corner of Alamo Square.  If you like architecture, check it out.

The Westerfeld House at 1198 Fulton.  Still, FYI, a single-family residence.

My interpretation:  http://static.px.yelp.com/photo/XGAcMRIAdjWYgVduYyK_jA/l
author: Randy F.

description: So...I attended Ida B. Wells High School for a few years, the alternative high school right by the park on the top of Hayes Street. I've always known we were high up and had decent views, but I never actually tripped that we had THEEE prized, million-dollar view...not until years after I left the school. Alamo Square Park is a tiny park, but high up on a hill. The park itself has several steep hills. Views from all around the park are beautiful, but people come from far and wide for The Postcard Row...aka The Painted Ladies...aka The "Full House" House. The ornately-kept Victorians of yesteryears with the modern cityscape in the back drop, we've seen it in a million postcards. If you can handle the heavy winds (on most but not all days), this is a great place to picnic. The hilly terrain makes it an ideal spot for Slip 'n' Slides. I've never partaken in the Slip 'n' Slide, I've only ever watched with envy as strangers  slid around with glee.
author: Helen L.

description:
Hi, my name is Tats and I live in Hayes Valley. OK, not quite as heart-rendering as making that statement with the more predictable double-initial ending, but still.

Having moved from the Lower Haight up the street to Hayes three months ago is still something I'm sometimes sheepishly embarrassed about. Even though it's not really the Valley but more Alamo Square, the punk in me is blushing. 

Correction - make that WAS. Not anymore. Not since yesterday, when i took a thermos full of beer, a blanket and a laptop and just parked my tired old ass in the park. All afternoon. I now love living half a block away from Alamo Square. The park is pretty, the view is great, there's tons of happy puppies to play with (and a community of responsible owners who take care of them) and there's, like, a dozen of open wireless networks you can log on to and siphon Internet off of. 

In fact, I enjoyed myself so much that I decided to play hooky as the weather was once again nice. And guess where I am RIGHT NOW! You got it. Gotta go, there's dogs to frolic with and tourists to mock in front of the Painted Ladies.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
on a nice day this place cant be beat.

very conducive to day drinking.

not as hippy infested as the park.
author: Jason B.

description: To keep it short and sweet, this is where you wanna go.  Well kept grounds, clean restrooms, lovely view.  If you enjoy watching tourists - this is the spot.  Hopefully you won't mind being in the background of someone's photo.
author: Mandy H.

description: Love this park, great for dogs and one of the main reasons why I moved close to it.  Great views of the city and friendly atmosphere.  I go 3 times a day to let my do out, close and convenient.
author: David K.

description:
What no fenced doggy area?!?!

Couldn't let poor Murphy loose to run around.
author: Howard T.

description: Beautiful park, Beautiful view, great ambience,  I really loved the little playground its perfect for kids and secured my baby really enjoyed it
author: Maryfer R.

description: Love the park, excellent location, great view, and always felt safe here and never approached for money or to buy crap.
author: John F.

description:
Today I discovered two good things:  the shoe garden, and the dog playground.  Just wandering over the hill to see the views, including the all-too-famous one, we discovered people playing with their dogs off leash.  Everyone was happy.  Then, in the southeast side, around an old permanently-locked restroom, we saw all these tree sections lining the walk.  Nailed to the tree sections -- shoes, often pairs of them.  Filled with dirt.  With plants growing in them.  

Street art at its best.
author: David D.

description:
How can you talk about Alamo Square and not reference "Full House"?!?  You just can't.  The last time I was here, I had the theme song stuck in my head.  

Oddly enough, I can't remember the grass ever looking as cleanly cut as it did in the opening shot.  

Situated along the infamous Bay to Breakers Hayes Street Hill, the views are great.  Have a picnic here, like the Tanners.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
You know what would be a good call?  Dressing up like Saget and Stamos (in that horrible late 80's sitcom gear) and staging a really angry, graphic 'domestic dispute' in front of the "Painted Ladies" for all the tour groups who roll by on their buses.

That'll give them something to photograph.

Oh, and Alamo is a good park for night time tree-climbing missions.
author: Ryan W.

description:
Ahhh, ahhh, ahhh, ahhh...
What ever happened to predictibility?
The milkman, the paperboy, evening TV.

Everywhere you look, everywhere you go (there's a heart)
There's a heart,
A hand to hold onto.

Everywhere you look, everywhere you go.
There's a face,
Of somebody who needs you.

Eveywhere you look,
When you're lost out there and you're all alone,
A light is waiting to carry you home,
Everywhere you look.
Everywhere you look.
Shubby-do-ba-ba-dow!
author: Viv C.

description: The Painted Ladies are a row of 7 Victorian houses or so located across the street from Alamo Square (park) on Steiner Street between Hayes and Grove.  There are great views of the houses and downtown from the park across the street and most of the time parking is not too difficult to find.  For the history of these homes, check out Wikipedia at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Painted_ladies.  This is a classic San Francisco photo spot and the weather is usually sunny here too even when it's foggy elsewhere in the city.
author: Chris F.

description: Almost right in the heart of the city this spot/park is a nice location to relax.  Watching the dogs and other tourists go by, it's kind of romantic with the city skyline in the background.  On that note, maybe sunset would be a good time to relax and take it in (though twin peaks on a clear night would be even better).  Lots of street parking to choose from make this a nice stop and smell the roses date location.
author: Brian Y.

description:
I like to get biscuits & cornbread from Eddie's Cafe on a sunny afternoon & sit in the park & eat. See? : http://www.flickr.com/photos/melisserlovesmook/114289993/

If you like people watching, this is a good place to go. Tourists, locals, doggies, they're all here. I also drive out-of-towners past the "Full House house", they like that.
author: Melisser E.

description:
I really like Alamo Square. I really only go for the dog park portion of the park, where I take my four legged boyfriend to fro lick with other canine creatures when the weather is amicable. There are always plenty of other pooches to play with and great owners. I have yet to encounter a rude owner or disrespectful dog. 
The park itself has several gentle slopes that hoomans and dogs alike can enjoy either for picnicking or (in the case of canines) running down to fetch balls or other toys of delight.
Be warned though, after rain or very damp weather the park can be a little muddy which makes for messy paws (easily fixed by a long walk home or the accompaniment of a towel) and sometimes balls get lost because they roll down the hill and look like about four other balls that may have been thrown down there as well. If your puppy isn't picky (like mine is) they'll be more than happy to bring back some body's ball for you to throw again. 
There is (of course) a drinking fountain for the dogs at the top of the hill. 
As I said- I am always on the dog side of the park. The other side (that faces the row of houses featured in the Full House opening) I have not visited. I get the impression from other reviewers that dogs must be on leash at all times on that side. For the dog side only aggressive dogs must be on leash.
Fun time on Christmas morning.
author: Sarah S.

description: Perfect setting for a picnic. Gorgeous green hills, big trees, sweeping views, dogs galore.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I live a block away- why don't I come here more often?

Gorgeous view of the city, even (especially?) when it's foggy.  If you love rando leash-free dogs bounding all up on you while you're quietly enjoying the view with a friend, this park is for you.  If that's not so much your thing, stick to the perimeter.  Worth hiking through to get to the single tennis court on a sunny day.  The courts are pretty well-maintained, busy on weekends of course.  And who doesn't enjoy feeling like they're in the middle of the Full House opening?  Don't lie.
author: Anna R.

description: Such a great park! Spent a couple of hours enjoying the sun, taking in the beautiful views of the city and of course snapping pics tourist style of the "Painted Ladies".
author: Rhonda G.

description: The most notable thing about Alamo Square isn't even in Alamo Square, it's the buildings across the street (on Steiner Street). Alamo Square park itself is a fairly small and very hilly park that includes basketball courts, a dog run, a field full of tourists photographing the famous row of 6 houses, and all the other features you'd come to expect from a public park. If you're just looking for a nice San Francisco park I'd recommend going to Mission Dolores which is better maintained and offers a better view of the city, Buena Vista which has lots of serene shaded paths to walk around, or of course Golden Gate Park for just about anything. For all intents and purposes this is actually a review of the painted ladies. A "painted lady" is actually the term for any Victorian or Edwardian styled home painted in 3 or more colors to enhance its architecture. Even though about 48,000 Victorian and Edwardian homes were built in San Francisco between 1849-1915, it's the series of 6 painted ladies at Alamo Square that were built between 1892-1896 that have become the most well known. What makes them so well known? Perhaps it's the view of the San Francisco skyline behind the buildings or their beautiful exteriors unobstructed by anything besides a few beautiful and well manicured trees (unlike the view of countless cables that obscure almost every view in the city) or maybe it's their use in countless movies, postcards, and television shows (most notably the opening credits for Full House). For you Full House fans out there, Alamo square and the painted ladies were featured in the opening sequence to the show but the Tanner family home was actually shown as being 1709 Broderick Street which is about 15 blocks north of the park.
author: Matt E.

description:
Updated Feb 2009

As new puppy owners, we have ventured into the magical world of SF Dog Parks only a little. Our little Shiba Inu is NOT an off-leash dog and the dog park here is not fenced. And it is near a bus line. And crazy-ass tour buses who hog the road. That being said, we do go over on-leash and the people are super friendly and really nice. Boo to the women skulking around trying to get people to buy her services as a dog photographer, but other than her our experiences have been good!

--------------------

I adore this park. It is safe, mostly clean (except for dog poo) and has great views. No, not of the painted ladies. . .go over by the dog park and look out west-ish. Cool. Especially at night - you can see the fog moving in and the towers of St. Ignatius. 

The shoe garden is a little ratty looking, but one of those quirky things that make me love SF. 

Unlike some city parks, I have no hesitation going here at night.
author: Sarcastic T.

description:
The moment I first stepped foot into Alamo Square, nostalgic memories began flooding back to me of sitting in front of the TV watching TGIF with my family as a young child. Images of DJ's bed comforter (that I so badly wanted), Kimi Gibbler's incessant rambling (being so grateful none of my friends were that annoying), Uncle Jesse hanging out with the Beach Boys (dude - how cool is that), Uncle Joey's signature phrase "cut it out" (wow - there are a lot of annoying people on this show). And how could I forget, the final word of the opening credits: Shoo-bi-doo-ba-bah-dow.

Now, Alamo Square is my favorite place to picnic in the city. The view of the Painted Ladies and SF skyline can't be beat ...bring some wine and crackers and brie and soak in those sunny SF days. 

(Note to dog-owners: while I love being able to pet your dogs and see them frolicking free, my "I so badly want a dog but can't because I live in a studio" thoughts quickly disappear when I encounter dog POOP where I want to set up my picnic blanket. Please please pick up the poop.)
author: Dalia K.

description:
An off-leash dog park a block from my apartment?  A park that not only provides amazing views, but also a doggie water fountain?  

With two big pups, this park is our stomping ground every morning & every night...  I'm the girl calling for Flash & Apollo or making gross faces after throwing their drool-covered ball.

The only reason the park gets 4 stars instead of 5 is the wind... Oh man, can it get cold up there!  It's tough to be at the top of the stairs seeing sun in Oakland while being bombarded by drizzly fog.  Scarf & gloves, anyone?
author: Jennifer H.

description: Finally get to see the "Full House House" LOL!!! ahhh... all my years and today I feel a little bit more accomplished..
author: Amy C.

description:
The view is awesome.  The higher up the hill you get, the more of the skyline you get.  It's not all about those painted ladies.

I went earlier in the day, so there didn't seem to be many tourists around.  I saw a few buses parked, but no people.  Hm... At least two of the streets have cleaning 12-2PM, so if you can sneak in before/after, parking is a breeze.

I wonder how much use the tennis court in the middle gets...
author: M C.

description:
Excellent old neighborhood park. A recent facelift gives this park so much beauty you'll forget while you sat there for hours just staring at the views. 
Also, a great place for watching meteor showers in the middle of the light-polluted city.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
painted ladies!! fan of full house? then this is a must on your tour of sf! praking can be a lil hard but you'll be able to find something!  on a nice day you can see far past the houses and makes for a great photo op.  

theres also a cool shoe garden in then middle!
author: Ashley G.

description:
It's unfuckwithable, historically speaking (as anything with a TGIF connection should be), but from a practical standpoint, you're mostly going to find people walking their dogs (one of the finer dog parks in this town) & Japanese tourists taking pictures of the painted ladies.

I'd give it three stars were it not for the fact that the last time I was there, a carload of girls with a megaphone were continuously driving around the park asking people what their favorite episode of 'Full House' was.

Three Words: Chinese Fire Drill. You know it's true! Okay, either that one or the one where Uncle Jesse gets dared to ride his motorcycle along the edge of a tall building & then at the last minute decides he loves DJ, Stephanie & Michelle too much to endanger his own life over a dare. A truely touching moment. But what's the deal with the continuous "AWWWW"ing of the studio audience anytime Michelle did or said anything? For chrissakes, she could've pooped on the rug & the whole place would've exploded with AWWWstruck people. Enough, already!

But I digress. It's pretty cool.
author: Pete J.

description:
Why yes, this is the park that is filmed at the opening to the show Full House! While this isn't my favorite park in the city, (GG park is) it still has it's perks. For one, on a clear day, it has one of the best views of downtown and is one of the prettiest backdrops for taking pictures for your holiday cards! Secondly, if you are not a dog owner you can be one of those creepy lurkers who just hangs out so they can pet other people's dogs all day.  Also great if you don't have a dog but want to meet a hottie with a dog. It's also good for kite flying. Because it's up on a hill with not a lot to block the wind, you get plenty of wind to hold up your kite.  Great for picnics as well.  

Or you can visit the shoe garden. Yes, there is a shoe garden there! it's a bunch of random shoes, heels, snowboard boots all nailed down and filled with plants to form a perfectly charming shoe garden. Lastly, it's a great place to go drink some brews with friends at night when the bars close. For those of you who are afraid of sitting in doggy poo, I haven't had too much of a problem with this. There is a main section of the park that the dogs and their owners hang out so as long as you stay away from there, you should be pretty good.
author: Jade L.

description: This is a quick trip hanging out at Alamo square and looking across the street at the painted ladies. This is a busy area so don't expect it to be peaceful and quiet. The row of houses are very pretty and interesting to view.
author: Ellie S.

description:
When I lived a couple blocks away from it, the boyfriend and I would regularly occupy one of Alamo Square Park's benches and chow down on some dinner picnic-style.

Part of me kept hoping that the Tanners would show up and have a picnic dinner with us.  But I guess they stopped hanging out there when Full House went off the air.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I [heart] my new 'hood.

Bonus points for telling all my friends in the midwest that I live next to the Tanners.

I always keep a lookout for the Beach Boys to drop by.
author: Matthew R.

description:
I live two blocks away and I love walking by the park when I take the #21 bus home. The previous week I sat on top of the hill in front of the Full House (whichever one it is) and read a book :). My favorite things to do here:

Introduce people to the shoe garden by the public toilets

a. Check out this article from the SF Chronicle about it.....worthwhile!
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/chronicle/archive/2003/05/24/HO99126.DTL&type=travelbayarea

b. And even better, I found this video on Brightcove, a beta site featuring the garden:http://www.brightcove.com/title.jsp?title=770018120

Swing on the swingsets
Fly a kite while the tourists take pictures
Point to one of the painted ladies and guess which house on the row was the infamous house. 

:)
author: Laura G.

description:
I understand being a tourist.  When I go to a big city that I've never seen before, I want to see it all.  But prior to me moving to the Western Addition, I would have never bothered to come to Alamo Square, let alone be able to call it by it's proper name.  Seven sisters?  Big whoop.  (Although, to be fair, I DO love the tourist who comes up and says "Look there it is!  Hey, which one is the Full House? Where is it?" -Um, if they keep things like that from the early 90's, it's on a sound stage in LA).

Okay, possibly the BEAUTIFUL view of the city on a clear day, but still, I prefer Twin Peaks for that, especially if I am a tourist and have a limited amount of time.  Or GG Bridge.  Do you know how many people have lived in this area and have never walked across it?  I think that is a travesty.

So, despite the beautiful view on a clear day, I still can't understand why any tourist would want to come here, take a few pics of the houses and then leave.  Is it to make yourself jealous of all the people lying around with their dogs who clearly live here and have nothing better to do today except sit on the grass, thank God for sunny days like this and the fact that they live in the best city in the world (in my humble opinion)?  Because that is the best reason to come here, to bask in your luckiness.  So, Alamo Square, despite the BUS LOAD of tourists that insist on standing ALL AROUND ME while I'm reading my book and getting some rays, you are currently the light of my life on a lazy sunny Sunday afternoon. For all the sunny clear days in San Francisco where I was just too lazy to go to the beach, GG Park or Dolores Park, Alamo Square, I salute you.
author: Alexis B.

description:
Beautiful, picturesque, not far from my apartment, and great for dogs and for humans. You gotta walk up a bunch of steps plus if you walk or jog around the entire park, it's great exercise. 

It doesn't get five stars because it's often a bit too chilly and windy up there.

**Edited to Add: Be sure to check out the quirky, cute shoe garden which is in the center of the park.**
author: Kimi W.

description:
Interesting park indeed. We sat in Alamo Square today on a lunch table and watched several tourist sight seeing buses come and go. If you have a dog, this is a very friendly dog park. The art near the bathroom is original and very cool. I liked how some clever and creative soul planted some flowers inside a ski boot. Wish I had my camera. The grounds were very clean and there is a huge tennis court and playground. A great place to sit and watch dog owners and tourists taking pictures of the postcard picturesque symbol of San Franisco....the Full House row. 
Bathrooms are open from 8am till 2pm on Saturdays. Not sure the hours for the rest of the week.
author: Meredith O.

description:
Full house house...

Fun to just look at and reminice the beginning part of the full house show.
It's a park so you can relax here and roll down the grassy hills, which is very rare in the crowded city of SF.
author: Realtor Karl B.

description: This park has got it all, beautiful views of the bay area, a tennis court nestled in a grove of trees and flowering bushes, lush greens to lounge around on! MY trip to SF isn't complete without an afternoon spent relaxing here.
author: S P.

description: Memorial Day weekend has been one of the most beautiful and sunny weekends in San Francisco. What better way to spend it than to go park hopping. Alamo square was one of the stops on our adventure, and my favorite one. Mostly because I got to introduce my new BFF to the Painted Ladies. After a year of living here, she had never been to Alamo Square! I know! I couldn't believe it either! On this sunny Saturday, the park was filled with people laying out on beach blankets, sharing packed lunches, and snuggling in the sun. It was the perfect day to show my friend the gorgeous view beyond the Painted Ladies.
author: Casi C.

description:
If we're writing about the park, I friggin love it! I think it's perhaps the best park for its size.  People say they like dolores park down south, but I can do without all that.  Ok, so the park is great, the shoe garden, the painted ladies, the actual ladies that are taking pictures of the painted ladies, and all the dogs.  However...stray from this grassy knoll two blocks in any direction and it looks like a too short video.  That's why I didn't move here.

Thumbs up to the park, thumbs down to everything around it.
author: Amir B.

description:
I am proud to state I have never seen a whole episode of that insipid TV show Full House.  Therefore, the review is about it from an unbiased person.  

This is a well used neighborhood park. There are:  Dogs abound!  Joggers ahoy!  Walkers everywhere!  Sun worshipers ubiquitous (on nice days)!  Gawkers all over the place!  Tour Buses ever present!

Great views, walkable paths, well kept grounds, decent but shady tennis court, and great accessibility on all four corners.  Oh yeah...I guess it is an icon as well.
author: Chris D.

description:
Hokey fun time nostalgia aside... great communal area for running your pup!

Go to Eddie's for breakfast afterwards.  

And don't forget to check out the shoe garden!!!!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
I'm not going to complain about everybody who wants to take their Full House pictures.  It's there, it exists, whatever.

The truth is that Alamo Square has a beautiful view and is always full of dogs bounding about.  Great things if I ever saw 'em.

It only loses a star for me because it gets so damn windy.

This review has inspired me to get off the damn internet and go up to Alamo to read.  See ya there.
author: Stef A.

description:
Really, what's this all about? I know it because of Full House, but really, that's about it. It's kind of small. You blink, you drive by it. Oh well, if you like Alamo Square, you should check ou Atla Plaza at Scott and Jackson. 
There's a pretty good view of the city from here.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
This is the best park I've been to located in the city. Of course it's historic and has beautiful views, but the best thing is that it really makes you feel like you're in the heart of SF (versus the more "hip,young, and chic" areas like SOMA). I love bringing my doggie here and I think she likes it a lot too. They have doggie bags in case you forget and usually on weekdays there are a group of doggies who are ready to play. 

The one bad thing about this place (pretty much like anywhere else in SF) is the parking. We had to drive around for a good 15minutes to find a spot.
author: Angela L.

description:
I'm never really a park person - I really don't know what to do there - so I can easily give this place a 5-star.  Hubby & I took my dog there for a walk because I wanted to take my dog out more, and yelpers recommended me this park. 

It was a very nice day in SF, and a lot of people and dogs were out in the park that day. I loved it that it lets doggies run wild in the center of the park, and everyone and every dog is friendly.  

The view is nice up there, though I personally think SF is just a very beautiful city, and it's easy to find a nice view spot.  There are also a lot of tall buildings that block most of the views, so it's not as cool as I thought it would be. 

Overall, hubby and I had a good time spending time there, taking pictures, and seeing our dog sniffing around. And I think my doggy liked it too.
author: HsuMeow L.

description:
first time i was there, it was raining. I played in the play structure waiting for my boyfriend with my bestfriend... in the rain. since he 
second time i was there with Sam and Mia and Jill, and Missy, and a whole bunch of people for an photograph intensive. Also, waited for my boyfriend because he was taking a test at school. but missed him
loved the shoe garden, i'm probably gonna put it at city hall. and then there were the big cute dogs. ALLL BAD. ALL BAD. Almost got dirt on myself. oh well, it was gonna be worth it! :D
author: Carolyn Y.

description: After 15 years of living in San Francisco, I finally made it up to Alamo Square.  It was completely by accident.  We decided to walk to Hayes Valley from Golden Gate park and ended up here.  Wow!  It really is a beautiful view and I can see why this place is photographed so much.  Standing up there I was really proud of my adopted home city and how beautiful it truly is.
author: Sean O.

description: There's a timeless quality to this place, or rather, a feeling of being frozen in time at Alamo Square. The Victorian houses, dogs frolicking...it's a place where hipsters and yuppies can coexist. It's great for people watching or grabbing a blanket and just relaxing and laying out in the sun.  It's a unique, little anomaly in the urban jungle of SF. Parking sucks if you're not from the area.
author: Monica N.

description: My heart just started beating fast thinking about waking up this hill. I like to put my headphones on real loud and charge up the entire hill as fast as my fat thighs can move me.  The view is nice I guess, but it's that much sweeter when you're drenched in sweat because you were trying to KOM it.
author: Soma S.

description:
The man and I went to this park to check out the dog park.  I had a good time we walked around a little bit.  Sat in the sun, talked, people and dog watched.  We met some cool people and their dogs, Phoenix got plenty of excercise.  

We got to see the the "Full House" house and the rest of the painted ladies.  We saw plenty of tour buses go by and a lot of picture taking, tourists, kids, and local people hanging out.  

The downside of this park  is the parking can be a pain. I think we just got lucky we parked right across the street.  It may not be so simple the next time.  There were parts of the park that were muddy, watch your step by the looks of my shoes I obviously did not, It was not shit.  Thank God! 
I will be back soon!
author: Maureen M.

description: This little park gives you a little bit of both - the old and the new.  The pretty Victorian houses and the gorgeous view of SF Financial District.  It's also a good people watching spot.  Alamo Square is included in every guide book, so it can be really crowded with tourists.
author: Lidiya B.

description:
A coworker took me this wknd to hang out here.  I know Alamo Square as where Danny, DJ, Stephanie, and Michelle Tanner from Full House would hug and make up after a very frustrating 20-min. family conflict.  Anyway, those houses are totally cute.  The square park area is pretty big.  We played frisbee, and I utterly suck.  But my coworkers were respectfully patient with my challenged fat ass.  They even gave me some tips.  Anyway, there were hella dogs... it was like some annual dog conference or something.  Dogs are cool, except for their doo-doo.  Doo-doo isn't too cool. 

The view is pretty nice here too.  The day was beautiful, so that made it that much greater.  Good ole SF!
author: Labonee M.

description:
So pretty.  Easily the prettiest place in the city, IMHO.  SOOOO  pretty.  God, how much do I love this park.  ITs not that big, and its on a big hill, which makes it much more of a hangout park than a sport playing park (which is fine by me).  There's a dog side, a tennis side and a sitting side.  The dogs kinda have the run of the place, but they're soooo cute and their owners are pretty good about picking up after them, so its not a problem!

Here's what you do: go here in the Early afternoon when its sunny and bring some wine and some cups.  You can bring beer if you want, but you might be told by the police to get out of here you crazy kids if they catch you with it.  Wine is much more mellow and respected by law enforcement.  So, yeah, you do that, and you bring some antipasto or little sandwiches with no crust and a bunch of your friends that you LOOOVE soo much.  We're talking heaven on the grass, real life wine and roses shit.  

There's an amazing view of the city, FiDi to Twin Peaks to Inner Richmond/Sunset.  Its perched up on little hill and is always in the sun, unless the stupid clouds have rolled in.

The only problem with this park is that it is often the windiest place in San Francisco.  If you come here anywhere close to sunset you're gonna get blasted soooo hard its gonna make you wish that you had brought that second jacket.   But the thing is, even if you HAD brought it, you'd still be cold and/or your friends would have forgotten theirs, so just know you're gonna have to leave when the sun gets low.

Only other drawback is that the tour buses drop people off here, which kinda harshes your mellow until you realize that you're living in a tourist destination and then you get ecstatically happy about how lucky a roll of the dice you got to be born into this life of yours.

Here's a super-secret secret:  this park is gorgeous at Sunrise.  I'd say start here at fool's dawn after a night of drinking and wait until daybreak.  No matter what kinda night you've had you're going to feel small and light.  Just don't talk loud.  That's not cool.
author: Bill P.

description:
Pancho's (my sweet 11 year-old black lab) favorite park that's walking distance from our apartment.  We're here nearly every day.  Beautiful views, lots of dogs.

One star off for having to see 20+ tourists on the same hill taking the same picture everyday.  Yeah, its the John Stamos house--who the F cares?  Look at the cityscape, you nimrods!
author: Jason B.

description:
Five stars just form my proximity alone, when I move further away two stars will automatically deducted.

Great views, as if every tourist and newlywed didn't know.

I love to watch people letting their dogs play in the leash free zone, which inevitably leaks to the non-leash free zone.  

The wind over the top is wicked fun for kite flying.

And the log at the top is perfect for some cyclocross practice.
author: Adrian L.

description:
I never knew the Tanners lived so close to the projects.  

Decent park for hanging out and reading a book, but too much of an incline to play a decent game of frisbee.  Could probably throw a football around though.  Popular among dog owners, so be sure to watch where you step.  The views are nice throughout the park, not just of the Painted Ladies, but of the northern and western sides of the city.
author: matt c.

description:
NOW we know why Danny Tanner didn't want DJ going to the dance late at night. NOW we understand where Joey was getting all of that crack cocaine. and NOW we've realized there's a reason Jessie had that AK-47 assault riffle stashed under his bed.
           -this is a great park! nice size, plenty of grass and trees, good views of the city, dogs, friendly people and the regretfully unavoidable busses FULL of tourists.
    all that being said, a great place to lay or sit in the sun and chill out a little bit. also a nice part of town to witness a drive by shooting. 
   oh yea, have you seen the shoe garden?
author: Pflip W.

description:
Come on people...the last thing I think about in this amazing San Francisco jewel is Full House.  SOOO over it.

Alamo square is where it is at - the heart of the city.  It is not about the painted ladies - not that I take anything away from the sisters - but, it is where the world falls in love with pre-1906 San Francisco.  

Yeah, love the people watching almost as much as the views of the city.  Does not get better than that.  So, grab your loved ones and camp out, picnic, play with your dog - or, any dog for that matter; mooches are welcomed - and, fall in love.

If you are into the Victorians, continue down Steiner and hit up McAllister, and the surrounding areas (including NOPA).  Although, I love the ladies, they are not my favorite in the neighborhood.  I am almost certain, if you continue to explore this amazing artistic and historic district, you will feel the same.  It is kind of like ice-cream, you should never stop exploring new flavors.
author: Kiki I.

description:
Yes this is where the full house credits are..ok big deal. If you go to the park you'll get over that in say i dunno 5 seconds? :)

We went to the park on an absolutely gorgeous day so my review will be a bit skewed. The park is not huge by any means, but there is a nice grass area overlooking the north west portion of San Francisco. Its a great view on a clear day.

There are many grassy areas, but quite a few of them are used by dogs so beware where you sit. The southwest corner of the park is the best view and the best place to sit. There is also a small children's playground in the middle of the park if you have kids.

The park was relatively quiet and peaceful. The intricate Victorian houses are cool to gaze at.

I'd say this park isn't the best to come with a bunch of people to play ultimate frisbee or something, but is better for a smaller group to share lunch or just relax and sleep.

Yay I love city parks! The end.
author: Varun ..

description:
The most beautiful majestic trees, I love the different seasons here with the willow trees sprouting in the spring. Forget the painted ladies and look around at some of the most beautiful manisons in the city closer to Scott & Hayes. Always an inspiring walk first thing in the morning with the dog.
The lady that looks after this park does an amazing job.
author: sarah l.

description: Spectacular views of the city.. parking is bad tho.. I was in search of the full house "painted ladies", wow.. thats it???  Lots of tourists takin photos of the houses, and dogs running around.  Boy it was hard to find!
author: La La T.

description:
I visited Alamo Square over the weekend and as I stood on the steps that overlooked a beautiful scenery of the city of San Francisco and the "Painted Ladies" or what's better recognized as the "Full House" house, it dawned on me that:

1. Why is this place called Alamo Square?
2. Which one of those houses was actually the Full House house?
3. Where can I find Uncle Joey?

Not! I don't really care about Uncle Joey, but the funny thing is... when I visited this place I couldn't help but to find it amusing how there were all these international tourists that came to check out this place and somehow all knew it as the the Full House houses. I mean was that show that big that these people really traveled millions of miles just to check out the Full House house? Sad to say, but according to Wikipedia "Contrary to popular belief, the red-doored Victorian where the Tanners live is not one of these houses. The address of the Tanner house was mentioned in "Blast From the Past" as being located at 1882 Girard Street in San Francisco, CA." and not to mention the show was never even recorded in any of those houses! So I don't even know why I refer to these houses as the Full House house or why I even get excited whenever I pass by this park. I guess somehow the Intro to that show fooled me into believing it was located there and that since it was featured on a popular TV show, being in the same vicinity as these houses just makes them cooler. But aside from all that, Alamo Square is a lovely park. I still have yet to venture off to the other side opposite to the Painted Ladies.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oSL_EvN1XqM
author: Ally C.

description:
Five stars for Alamo Square Park on a hot friday night!!!

 Full House....bitches.

Yeah we were the drunken girls running around the park last friday, rolling in the grass and cartwheeling through the expanses. The view is tremedous of both the city and the painted ladies. Shoe garden brings something new and unexpected to the picture.

 Opting for something other than the biker trash kids and fist fights of Dolores park for a change, we braved the hill and found ourselves in a quiet green happy park. Contemplating the cocaine usage of previous Full house stars and chatting with passer bys. What a great use of our girls night out.

On a side note dont stay to late unless you are accompanied by a bodygaurd the neighborhood is shady and it is a park afterall.

Never a dull moment.
author: Charlie B.

description:
This park is in my new neighborhood and I love it!  I hope I never take it for granted when I'm on the 21 Hayes everyday!  Today was a beautiful day and I picked this park to sit and read for a couple of hours.  In some spots it could be really windy but in other spots, I was fine.  There were many tourists around but that didn't bother me.  Besides, the whole time I was there I could only focus on one thing.  And that was the following song replaying in my head.

Are you ready for this...
 
Ahhh Ahh Ahh Ahhh Ahhhhhahhhh
What ever happened to predictability? 
The milk man, the paper boy, evening T.V
You miss your old familiar friends, but 
waiting just around the bend. 

Everywhere you look (everywhere)
There's a heart (there's a heart)
A hand to hold on to.
Everywhere you look (everywhere)
There's a face of somebody who needs you.

When you're lost out there and your all alone
A light is waiting to carry you home
Everywhere you look.
author: Dominique T.

description: This is one of the best spots in the City on a rare late summer evening when it's unbearably hot during the day, but perfect when the sun is just starting to go down.
author: A D.

description:
I was there the other day, for the first time in years. 

Loved it.

Question: which one of the Painted Ladies did the Tanners on "Full House" live in? And why was their proximity to Alamo Square not referenced in the show?
author: Alex S.

description:
windy hill-top park with a little bit of everything!

off-leash dog area for the poopy puppy.

paths for your walking pleasure.

benches for your lazy ass.

tennis court covered in branches and pine cones for your amateur match.

playground for the munchkins. 

those houses from "full house" so you can stand next to a gang of fresh-off-the-bus tourists and take the same damn picture that everyone has already taken a million times, then bring it home and show your friends and say "hey, guys. you remember 'full house?!'"

word to the wise: DO NOT walk through the north-east quadrant of this park during extremely windy conditions. the massive monterey cypress trees are notorious for calving branches the size of a house while under gale force.
author: zachary p.

description: This place holds some sentimental memories, as we got our dog here. Adopted him from someone else and met the little monster here for the first time. My problem being, there is no fenced in area I can let my dog off the leash and as he has gotten older, he really cannot control himself off the leash. But it's a beautiful park and I love walking here....just not with the dog.
author: Jena D.

description: A magic place, particularly in the morning when the professional dog walkers occupy the hill above the Seven Painted Ladies. If you want to take the photo you see in all the guidebooks, it's better around 5 PM, you will have the sun in your back. Now the thing to do, once you have seen Alamo Square is to continue along Clayton Street and walk up to Haight Ashbury.
author: CasimirVessel

description: I came here last Friday for some sightseeing. The park itself was well kept. I saw a few dogs roaming. I didn't see any dog poop. Oh, and nice green grass. I loved the view of the Painted Ladies and the skyline in the background. A good day out, and the view was a plus.
author: Ashley B.

description: You know the face, but you can't remember the name . . . most people never knew it in the first place, but everyone in the world recognizes that row of well-maintained Victorians with the downtown skyline serving as their backdrop as being the quintessential San Francisco scene. Every TV show and movie set here uses it as an establishing shot, especially if they're filmed in Vancouver.  Welcome to my backyard - or front garden, if you will, as I live on one of its corners and have a smashing view of all that greenery. It's never more beautiful (or eerie) than when shrouded in fog at dawn, never more crowded than at the height of tourist season, when busloads of camera-toting visitors invade it to snap pix of the Painted Ladies. From other vantage points you can see that lone tall white apartment building towering above Pacific Heights, and on a clear day the top of the Golden Gate Bridge. I love to sit here and read mid-afternoon, before everyone gets home from work and dashes over to let Fido run free. Some day I hope to own one of those famous houses and paint it black or hang a huge sign that says 'F*CK YOU' just to freak out the photo fiends. In the meanwhile, join me on my bench and chat for awhile.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
"By far, the easiest way to befriend a large group of white people is to organize and then participate in a game that is normally played by children."

http://stuffwhitepeoplelike.com/2008/06/02/102-childrens-games-as-adults/

When I got word that a pick-up game of capture the flag was being arranged, I of course jumped at the chance to play; I'm genetically predetermined to. The venue was Alamo Square, and the organizers were (surprise!) a bunch of my kickball friends of the pigmentally-challenged persuasion. 

It started with a few libations at Madrone and The Page (cause children's games apparently can't be played without adult beverages), and then it was off to the park. With the teams dressed in camouflage or head-to-toe ninja black and the sun setting behind us, we were ready to enter stealth mode and get down to business. Some of us (um, me) even brought ninja stars and a sai. Battle lines were drawn, the jails were stocked with 30 packs of Bud Light, and we squared off. Truly, this was no kiddie version of capture the flag.  

It was an epic clash, with each team having secured one victory (simultaneously, at that) and the deciding match on the line. By now, it was well into hour two of what historians have already dubbed "The Battle of Alamo (Square Park)", and this girl desperately needed to use the little soldier's room. But these are times of war, people, and there's no running across the street to use the gas station loo in such critical circumstances. Besides... the sidewalk was out of bounds.

So, I found myself an appropriately sheltered bush located behind my team's jail, and assumed the position. With my spandex around my ankles, and a stream of relief exiting my body, I suddenly heard the crunch of the leaves made by an enemy approaching. With my adversary unaware of my position, I laid in wait for the opportune moment to unleash my impromptu defensive strategy. Just as my foe was about to turn the corner of my enclave, I said to him in my most menacing tone,"Take one step closer buddy and you'll be entering a world of pain... and by pain, I mean urine." Suffice to say, the kid BOOKED it back to his side, and away from his intended goal. Point: Anna K.

While I'm usually not one to toot my own horn (you hush), I think its pretty safe to say I piss all over the competition.
author: Anna K.

description: Sometimes on moonlit windy nights after a bit too much Maker's Mark, I sprint up to the tip top of Alamo Square Park and yell "Remember the Alamo!" Sometimes on bright days I stretch out on the grass and try to determine where the crowns of trees end and where the sky begins. Sometimes my old shoes go missing in my closet and I find them stuffed with earth and pansies in the garden at Alamo. Sometimes on Valentine's day there is a park bench I reserve with red caution tape that says "Love Crime About to be Committed". Sometimes in a headband and wooden raquet, I say "Game, Set, Match....shall we have a cocktail now?" Sometimes the downtown skyline leaps so fiercely to my eye I think I am going to explode with the weight of the ancients. Sometimes trees bend deeply at Alamo. The whole park folds. Alamo: where the grass is always greener, no matter which side.
author: Cpt. Scallywag N.

description: FYI - The opening credit house for Full House is at 1709 Broderick Street, between Bush and Pine.  Dont be fooled - they painted the red door black.
author: Michelle C.

description: Alamo Square has a pretty view. I first went here with friends last summer...on a spontaneous trip to SF. The Painted Ladies are pretty. The Full House house isn't on this street (FYI). It's a nice place to have a picnic though!
author: Jackie J.

description:
best place to drink a 40 while getting stabbed in the ass with a needle!

oh and dog watching is fun too!
author: Ishmael V.

description: I'm like any 30 something person who lived outside SF... only knew about the "painted ladies" from the show Full House. I was surprised how nice of a park this was. Nice views of the painted ladies, which I found it funny my friend thought they were statues, nice area for dogs on and off leash, grassy areas for picnics, scenic views all over, and plenty of photo shots. This is SF so always be prepared in case of  windy or cold weather, I think I saw a girl from The Hills blow away while there. Place has a public restroom and checked out the shoe flowers around it, which makes for good pictures. You will spend about 10 minutes looking for parking on nice days but well worth the visit.
author: Mike D.

description:
i don't think i'd ever done much more than drive by the painted ladies (FULL HOUSE HOUSES OMG!) until i started working at a-house-that-shall-not-be-named across the street from it. 

and then, i loved it more than anything else.

perhaps it was the fact that the-house-that-shall-not-be-named was the craziest, most stressful environment i have ever worked in, but there was just nothing like escaping on a break to the solitude of this park. here, i could clear my head. here, i could smoke cigarettes without prying eyes. here, i could have phone conversations without prying ears. and here, i was just far enough away that i didn't have to hear any of the sounds from inside. 

siiiiiigh.

that's how this park makes me feel: one giant sigh of relief.

also, good for both dogs and kids.
author: Irene S.

description: Perfect place on a sunny day for a boy with his dog, his book, and nothin' much to do but wait for his boyfriend.
author: Kevin S.

description: This is the park by my house, so it's dear to me. It's also got some serious breathtaking views like Dolores & Buena Vista, but they don't have a wall of parking built around them for the tour buses. It can get windy here in the afternoons due to it's hilly nature. They have a cute little garden area where old shoes & boots are filled with plants, I just love that. There's also tennis courts and a puppy play area.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Easter Sunday. Spending time with the new person in my life. The wind is refreshing and crisp and the sun is shining and I am grinning from ear to ear. We're both a little low on funds and agree to not drink until a certain designated hour. How to pass the time?
I begin the walk up Fulton with my sparkly new special friend walking hand in hand. He asks where we are going? I tell him I have a surprise for him. He looks at me inquisitively but goes along. 
We approach the park and he halfheartedly grumbles about the last uphill hike. Once we turn to look at the first view all complaining leaves. He is smitten and so am I. Hee hee. 
The views here are smashing, doggies and children playing around are uplifting, it screams bring a picnic, bring a kite, bring a camera, bring someone special. I highly also recommend bringing a bottle of soap bubbles (see my Burma Superstar review) as they are fun and really when was the last time you went to the park to blow bubbles? If you can't remember and/or it's been over decade go and buy some darn you! It'll cost you all of about a buck and a few minutes at Alamo on a bench blowing bubbles and you'll magically centered, happy and content with the world. I promise. Life can be sweet.
author: Veronica G.

description: Great dog park. It has a big designated off leash dog area. I take my dog here almost every day and he enjoys it. There is plenty of space to toss a ball around and lots of trees and bushes for him to sniff.
author: Abhi A.

description: The park where some of the most romantic moments between my boyfriend and I took place will always hold a special place in my heart.  I love to watch the dogs let off the leash running and circling with all their little doggie energy around the hills, so happy to be alive and free until they roll around on the grass in pure ecstasy.  I love the trees in bloom and the rare, hot nights, when sitting barefoot in the grass on a blanket counting stars is the preferred pastime.  So much more than the place where forgotten TV shows and movies were filmed and where tourists take pics of Victorian Row.
author: Jill D.

description: If i lived in SF and anywhere near this park i do believe that Joshua and i would be here every day.  There were lots of cute doggies having fun.  The grass is really nice to lay on.  And you can see the Full House houses.  Tits.  Lots of foreigners taking pictures...
author: desiree n.

description: If I'm ever reborn as a dog, I'm going to drag my owner here to play every day. But until then (or until I get a dog, in which case he/she can gladly drag me!), I'll just have to enjoy the human side of things - picnics on blankets, reading in the shade, sunning on the grass. Lots of room, fresh air, sweet views. Mmmmm, simply peaceful.
author: Kai S.

description:
concern of summer 2008: how will i get tan in the city?

answer: alamo square!

lazy sunday (or lazy lazy thursday in the summer) has now translated to a particular hill, dogs, headphones on, telephone off, laptop gone, perfect read, over-sized shades,  and some of the best views.
author: Coco E.

description:
7am, dogs splash in puddles
still pooled from long past rains, 
golden dome glittering.

Skyline fades in, fades out.

Transamerica shamelessly postures, 
black windows winking darkly.

The fog veils the slumbering ladies,  
tucked up side by side, painted faces framed  
with matching lace, faintly awry. 

Shoes stuffed with earth,  
bloom amidst cracked mirrors, 
neatly paired. My face, wavers in the glass. 
Someone's altar.

Stooped at the foot of a weeping willow, 
the gardener bends, a small white flower
